There was only one incident reported where I excitedly ran towards a woman and jumped up, there was no one to yell 'brace yourself', dad said she was fine with it and no legal action will be taken. Once the line of questioning was exhausted I could finally receive my coming home treats, of course I first got a warm cloth rub down on my belly, just in case it's muddy, even with her separation anxiety she still has cleaning issues. It was wonderful to run free and to come home smelling like fresh linen, The Warden says that she doesn't remember it smelling like this, that's the anxiety talking.

After each snow storm it's important to inspect the yard, first of all to make sure the staff has cleared enough yardage to do my business and to get in some recreational sniffing. Plus The Warden 'likes' to pick up all daily deposits (it's a relative term, it's a necessary job one does, liking it does not apply), let's say she has issues leaving any job unfinished and has taken it upon herself as the official poop-picker-upper (technical term). So far this winter there has not been any rabbit droppings to pick up which is an added bonus and less time consuming, which should mean she has more time to devote in the kitchen and giving me extra attention. As a side note, take time each day to show you care, be kind and thoughtful, sometimes just offering cheese says it all, Ancient Basset Saying.

title: Too much excitement yesterday starting with The Warden laying on the couch in the middle of the afternoon to watch TV, so that changed my whole routine, I had to lay on the couch with her. There was hooting and hollering, which unnerved me, it was worse than a Proud Mary Moment (no evening juices were involved). They were watching the World Junior Hockey Championship which Canada won, you would think that they could've offered snacks, at least a small platter of cheese per person, apparently someone with issues doesn't snack mid day, we're in a crisis situation, send help. As a side note, when celebrating any major event it's important to offer 'others' a snack of some substance (eg. small cheese platter, deli assortment etc.), it's about doing the right thing, Ancient Basset Saying.

media.title: When you get a freshly washed blanket on your lounger, tucked in with hospital corners, it's important to set the stage. First of all get a gravy coated biscuit, moisten it so it sticks to the blanket, don't worry about gravy stains, the staff have extensive training in all things that need to be cleaned, take your time chewing the biscuit, leave enough crumbs to snack on later and of course with the right amount of hair and slobber it gives you that comfy homey feeling. Depending on your energy level you may want to rough up the blanket a little, untuck a few corners, the eye twitching will be your guide to the level of satisfaction you require before you lay your head down. This is your sanctuary, don't settle for anything less, add more crumbs, hair or slobber, surround yourself with the finer things in life (if cheese is not available) Ancient Basset Saying.

Being just a tiny slip of a girl you sometimes have to have a larger than life personality in order to get the attention you deserve. There have been references made to when I gracefully glide along the floor as sounding like a herd of thundering hooves or when an unnamed person (with control issues) often says 'brace yourself' when I jump up for a happy greeting, these comments are coming from someone who is desperately seeking attention. Apparently when your world tour of singing and dancing was cancelled due to lack of talent you start to lash out in desperation. I have learned to take the high road and ignore these outrageous comments, that's why I've developed selective hearing, say what you will because I only hear what I want to hear, Ancient Basset Saying.

When you're put in the position of giving neck rubs you do not, I repeat, do not ask where's the neck, it's rude. What you do is insert your hand in the general area of the neck folds and gently rub in a circular motion until your wrist starts to get that tingly feeling, it's a sign to switch hands. Don't be afraid to switch things up, I'm open to a deep ear or a chest rub, you're basically in the same general area so surprise me but keep the motion flowing. If I start moaning it probably means you're losing your focus, this is not a multitasking job unless you consider using both hands as multitasking. As a side note this activity may create a large accumulation of hair, it's a sign of a job well done, take pride in what you do, Ancient Basset Saying.

Throwback to that rare moment in time when I didn't steal The Wardens chair but I had a valid reason why. If you remember back to a few days ago when I won the lottery and was given a rib roast bone, The Warden spread out a blanket on the floor to protect the carpet from getting the remnants of slobber and roast bone juices, well that blanket was thrown over my lounger 'unwashed'. It was like sleeping on a pillow from heaven, it was covered in crusty fat leftovers, I licked off the larger pieces and had sweet dreams while snuggling on the roast memories. I'm not sure why the blanket wasn't rushed immediately to the washing machine but in this case it's best to let sleeping dogs lie, Ancient Basset Saying.

On this first day of the new year I plan to nap most of the morning, it enhances my overall health, around brunch I'll hang around the fridge waiting for cheese because I have a tendency to have low cheese levels which can lead to a cheese deficiency. Later I'll try to steal someone's chair, this is an expression of love, who doesn't love a warm seat. This evening The Warden and I will lay out on the couch, sharing is caring, at least until I need to stretch and rotate, The Warden will make the sacrifice and teeter on the edge because she wouldn't want me to cramp up. Spending time together, saying kind words of encouragement, getting lots of attention and scratches, these are all on my list for bringing in the new year. Be thoughtful of all your decisions and offer lots of cheese, Ancient Basset Saying.

In closing out the year The Warden has chosen a few pictures which adds colour to her day and lifts her spirits. Over the past year we've had a few bumps in the road but we've laughed and made the best of each day, could we have had more cheese, yes, and we will continue this pursuit in the new year. A special thank you to everyone for taking the time to share your own story, for making us laugh and sometimes cry, that's what we do as a family, our IG family makes us feel special. Remember when you want to make someone feel special it's about spending time together and offering cheese, Ancient Basset Saying.

It was a rough start this morning, had to have an emergency crew help me get outside. It was freezing rain and the back deck was glare ice, so dad covered it in ice melt but I was still slipping and sliding so I turned around and came back inside. That's when The Warden (maintenance manager) had dad spread lots of ice melt all over, once that was done I ventured out again, tentatively, nose to the ground, inching my way along until I hit the crispy grass. I had an audience watching my every step, it felt like I had cheerleaders applauding my every move. Once I had a quick pee I immediately headed back inside where I got a gentle paper towel pat down, lots of praise for my heroic adventure and one treat. As a side note, this traumatic experience was worthy of at least two treats or a cheese platter, just saying.

title: My brother is home for a visit so as a gracious hostess I'm sharing my spot on the couch, for a small price, lots of attention and scratches. He doesn't worry about the small stuff like being covered in hair or slobber, I provided enough to wrap up in a gift bag. If I'm up early enough I like to slip past The Warden and sneak downstairs to see if he's awake, it's called the crash and bang, hard to sleep through a basset morning wake up call. The Warden usually issues a warning, make sure the door is closed if you plan to sleep in otherwise expect company who will whine until they get a lift service up on the bed. It's not really a whine it's a soft whispering breeze floating through the air announcing I'm here.

When you've gone to the trouble of yanking a throw off a chair the chances of giving it up are zero, unless of course there are incentives. I first of all had to jump up on the arm of the chair, grab hold and start yanking until it hits the floor, once that was done with some barking of course, you firmly hold your ground and don't move, the only thing getting me to move is a crane. As a side note, if you want to ensure you get your full compliment of attention it's advisable to cover all access points, this speeds up the negotiation process, Ancient Basset Tip.

media.title: Rules to follow while eating a rib roast bone, yes, there are rules, no free style'n, you must adhere to the rules and regulations as laid out by management. First of all stay on the blanket that has been spread out for you to dine on, if you happen to stray off the staff will make any necessary adjustments, they might as well do something while they're hovering close by. After you've thoroughly cleaned off the bone you'll need to do a cleanup, do this by repeatedly rubbing your face along the carpet switching from side to side, another option would be the couch (my personal favourite), your choice. If you're lucky a little fat will crust on your gravy dippers and you'll be even luckier if you don't get chased by someone with a wet cloth.

title: Throwback to the sunny summer days where my blanket would be spread out on the manicured lawn, my bowl filled with fresh filtered water with ice, the staff would be lurking in the shadows and I prayed for somebody to walk by so I could bark at them, the good ole days. During the winter months and with the busy holiday season it's important to take some time to reflect on those special moments, to dial it down a notch but always be on full alert in case the fridge door opens. It's advisable you get your full compliment of naps, be sure to hydrate with gravy and have plenty of aged cheese to prevent a cheese deficiency, Ancient Basset Saying.

media.title: All I want for Christmas is time spent with you, someone to be by my side, to give me scratches and rubs till I fall asleep, to watch me with a smile while I do a yank and drag while barking, and most of all to share a platter of cheese, one for you two for me. Time spent together is a gift that keeps on giving, take time to listen while others tell you a story, smile when you say everything will be alright and appreciate those quiet moments together. Do I want that roast bone covered in meat, of course I do but what's more important are those moments when I look up and you are watching over me. Merry Christmas to everyone and enjoy those special moments with family and friends.

I went to the train station to pickup my brother, the place was packed, people coming and going, there was no parking, it was total chaos, how would he ever find me in this crowd. There was only one solution, dad rolled down the window, I stuck my head out, reached as far out the window as I could and howled, all of a sudden out of the massive crowd my brother came running, somehow he found us. Other people started coming over to our car but we only had room for one, The Warden would've had a meltdown if we brought home a bunch of strangers. My brother got in the backseat because I called shotgun, which he didn't mind, he was just happy to be home and looking forward to sharing cheese with everyone. When you're in a tight spot and unsure what to do, start howling, Ancient Basset Saying.

There are times when I'm outside I like to imagine I'm exploring the great unknown, sniffing the footsteps of wild predators, hunting down those that dare cross my path in the urban jungle. Forget the fences that surround the yard, imagine the wide open spaces, the untamed wilderness, your nose to the ground heading up the street to the neighbours, block out the imagine of dad chasing after you in his slippers. While on this dangerous journey you glance up and there lurking in the shadows is The Warden, which reminds me it's time to get out of the cold and go inside for my treat. Don't be afraid to explore the great unknown as long as there's cheese at the end of the road, Ancient Basset Saying.

Dear Santa, first of all you look lovely in red, it highlights your cheeks, secondly I thought I'd save you some time and highlight how I got to the top of the nice list over the year. If it wasn't for me The Warden would be wandering around lost looking for a purpose in life and I'm her reason for staying on the right road. Have I whined, barked, begged, put hair in the air, did a few yank and drag while barking, of course, but it all doesn't compare to what I've given back. My list is small as I'm just a slip of a girl, every day I'd like a cheese platter for medicinal purposes of course and on a weekly basis a small roast simmering in gravy served on a large plate so my gravy dippers have a purpose. Thank you for your kind consideration and I've left out some gravy coated biscuits for you.

I like routine, predictably and everything in its place, so at a certain time each day when I start to 'act out', this should come as no surprise. I'll start off with a little whine, tail starts swishing, looking for direct eye contact, if that doesn't happen I'm left with no choice but to bark (your fault not mine). You may try to avoid eye contact by hiding behind your book or try totally ignoring me, well how's that working for you, it's just best to submit and give me the attention I require. It's not much to ask for, a little me time, might as well give me rubs until your wrist starts to hurt then change hands, look deep into my eyes and tell me what a good girl I am. It's all about spending quality time together and doing nice things, be kind to each other and share cheese, Ancient Basset Saying.

In order to understand the urgency level of going outside you have to know the signals but also understand that this level could change at a moments notice. If it's a one scratch at the door it's considered a low level, take your time getting there, if it's a two scratch start moving, a quick three succession scratch is at a high emergency level which requires you to sprint to the door. Here's where it gets interesting, if the door opens and there's a blistering cold -20 temperature, where it slaps you in the face and takes your breath away, there will be some hesitation and you may rethink your options. Yes I'll eventually stroll out but no amount of urging will help and a little tap on the butt only delays process, so if you're the door handler take a deep breath and know that you'll eventually warm up.

Throwback to the time The Warden thought she was an artist and used me for inspiration, she might as well put her lurking skills to use. Don't get me wrong she has other ambitions, remember the time she wanted to travel the world and entertain everyone with her singing and dancing, unfortunately the tour got cancelled due to lack of talent. At home we let her express herself, it's a non judgmental safe space, well it's also because of the restraining order and she can only shimmy with us as her audience. It's a small sacrifice to make but as long as there's cheese it's one I'm willing to take.

Sometimes bad things happen to good girls, here's the real unfiltered story. The Warden came home with a shopping bag (cloth, reusable) and after she emptied the bag she set it on the floor, which to me was an open invitation to inspect, I stuck my head inside (as one does), somehow I got my head stuck and couldn't get it out. I was trapped inside, I couldn't see anything, I started bumping into things blindly, I knew I wasn't alone because I heard 'oh for heaven sake', it was The Warden coming to my rescue, I could hear the concern in her voice, she wasn't in a panic so I knew everything was going to be alright. Fortunately I was rescued from this frightful experience, would I do this again, probably, lesson learned, make sure first responders are in the same room, Ancient Basset Saying.

When dealing with extreme weather you must adapt to your environment and pray that the staff have stocked up on all your favourites so you don't become weak from hunger. Even if you can't go out on long walks for your daily cardio regime you still have to maintain your fluffiness, also extra hair in the air keeps the staff from becoming lazy, just thinking of others. As a side note, while napping keep one ear on high alert, 'tis the season for sneaking snacks, the other day I found The Warden hiding out in the laundry room nibbling on a piece of cheese, she's shameless. If all of a sudden it becomes eerily quiet don't assume they are not sneaking snacks, immediately hunt them down, Ancient Basset Saying.

How do I cope with extreme weather conditions you ask, well I do a lot of watching it from the inside and throw in a couple of yank and drag while barking. In summary we had a day of rain which got rid of the snow, then it snowed which was heavy with rain and then it started to freeze. The snow crew had to react quickly to remove the wet snow in the backyard before it froze so I could go outside, before I went out they sprinkled ice melt (pet friendly) so I wouldn't slip. Weather Watching can also deplete your cheese levels, use caution and replenish on a regular basis, Ancient Basset Saying.

Does the hair on the back of your neck stand up suddenly and you start to get the feeling you're being watched, this happens every time I steal a chair. This wasn't a vacant chair, it was an out and out steal and a proud moment I might add, just look at that twitching eye and the hesitation about what to do.  There's one thing I know for sure, I'm not moving, it'll take a crane to get me outta here, or, here it comes, a piece of cheese, let the negotiations begin. Don't always assume it's you that has to make the first move, wait it out, good things happen to those that wait, Ancient Basset Saying.

title: I spun out while taking a tight turn on one of my runs, I tripped over an ear, not to worry, I quickly recovered and started sniffing.  Never give up, being an athlete comes with challenges especially during the winter season, stay focused and keep your head up when taking a tight turn. It could also be due a slight cheese deficiency which can occur when you're being deprived of your daily requirements, at this point the authorities haven't been notified but I'm hoping for a miracle platter of cheese waiting for me inside, medicinal purposes of course. Keep your head up while running especially around corners, Ancient Basset Saying.

media.title: What is considered treat worthy and what qualifications do you need to make these decisions, something to ponder about today. Full disclosure, this has nothing to do with cheese as cheese is considered a necessity not a treat. When I go outside to do my business I am rewarded with a treat, now if I go outside and sniff the air and look around without leaving the deck I don't get a treat. They are sending mixed messages, as soon as I leave the threshold of the door I should qualify for a treat, but no, someone watches my every move, when you think about it this is all about them, they have control issues. I think we need to regulate who makes decisions about treat distributions, treats are needed as a motivational tool, Ancient Basset Saying.

title: We were having snow squalls so I thought this was a good time to throwback to the urban jungle and also to remind you that over the winter months it's important to keep your cheese levels up. I probably don't need to mention, but I will, it's also roast simmering in gravy season, for health reasons of course. Over the winter months you may appear extra fluffy but that's to be expected, in order to maintain your ab definition make sure you do a few extra stretches and rotations during your naps. This community service message was brought to you by Miss Lilly.

media.title: I've learned over time to tune out the madness of the daily cleaning ritual, it happens every day so you adapt while you nap, Ancient Basset Saying. Fortunately The Warden avoids vacuuming while I'm snoozing at least in this room. It all becomes white noise after awhile, the rattling and clanging in the kitchen, the hum of the Dyson and the constant hovering over me just to make sure I'm doing alright. Yes you learn to adapt to your environment, the good, the bad and the constant pursuit of cheese.

Not every yank and drag includes a session of barking, most do because it gets the eye twitching but there are times when I just run out of steam. Now I may have forgotten to mention that I've already successfully yanked the blanket off my lounger twice and dragged it around the room while barking, full disclosure. Each time The Warden will replace the blanket and do her hospital corners, it's like a nervous tick, she just can't help herself, did I happen to mention she has issues. I'm her therapy, without me she would have no purpose, it's about giving back to those that need attention, together we make a great team.

Being just a slip of a girl has its drawbacks, one being a low drop zone (peeing close to the ground), this happens when nature calls before the snow crew is activated. I understand that nothing can be done about the snow blizzard hitting you in the face as you're having a concentrated moment, it's a vulnerable moment, especially when you have lurkers watching your every move. These moments of trying times can easily become a faint memory by receiving a platter of cheese after your rub down with a warm fluffy towel, Ancient Basset Tip to ease all hardships.

The Warden had to defend my honour and in doing so she had to compromise her integrity, she stretched the truth a tad. While out on our walk we ran into one of our regulars and his four legged, black curly haired, non shedding, non barking, non drooling and aloof walking buddy. I went over to do a meet and greet when the gentleman suddenly backs up out of reach and says 'is that drool', I had two glorious lines hanging from each side of my mouth, impressive. The Wardens tone suddenly shifted, she explained that it's excitement drool when I meet other dogs, he asked her if I did this in the house, of course she said 'no, only on our walks when meeting others', this is where she compromised her integrity. In his defense, as if he needed one, he was dressed all in black, of course there is no excuse for bad manners, Ancient Warden Saying.

Yes, you heard it here, the sound of silence is golden but there are times when you need to be heard. I could see The Warden through the window and she was saying something, I couldn't hear it over the barking, she was probably saying hey hey, she's clever that way. Who doesn't love to hear a little enthusiast barking, someone expressing joy, spreading the love around, get your butt out here and chase me around, let's get this party started, I was expressing myself and feeling good. You can't stifle a Basset enthusiasm, Ancient Basset Saying.

When you're outside anything goes, let the slobber fly and go ahead and bark because once you're inside there are a few rules or as I refer to them as suggestions. The Warden likes her rules, it's really a sign of self esteem issues, she tries to be the pack leader with her hey heys but all you need to do is avoid eye contact. Her secret weapon is to control access to the aged cheese, that's why we must all stand together and make cheese accessible #freethecheese

title: Throwback to my baby years where all I had to do was whimper and the staff would come running to lift me up on the furniture. Of course there were lots of rules, one being no getting up on the furniture, well let's first put a blanket on the furniture and be careful when you lift her up, yes things changed over time. Now when I'm on the couch with the blankets tightly tucked in I'll start making a nest by first ripping up the blankets into a nice pile, everyone will start nudging each other and thinking isn't this so cute, yes things have definitely changed. I've gotten a bit older and I'm still yanking blankets around but over time the staff have learned to adapt and adjust their rules accordingly.

My behaviour was called into question but in my defense it was a barkable moment, here's what happened. As I was meandering from room to room I noticed something out of place, I didn't know what it was so I alerted the family, The Warden came running all in a flap concerned about intruders, turns out it was the vacuum filter drying on the floor vent (probably a violation and this picture will be used as evidence). As you can clearly see any and all barking was warranted, I rest my case, when in doubt start barking, Ancient Basset Saying.

The yard is a blank canvas but totally unacceptable for me to complete my daily requirements so I'm heading back inside until after the snow crew have finished the cleanup. If the snow is up to your knees or above then you need to bring in the professionals, I do have standards and I can wait it out. When I first went out only half the stairs were cleared off and I almost had to dive into the snow but I did manage to pee which seemed to be important to the staff. Not to worry, after an hour I was back outside to do a final inspection on yard and found it acceptable for part two of my daily requirements.

media.title: It's soup making season so be on high alert, make sure you have your listening ears finely tuned. First you'll hear the shredding of the vegetables, stay where you are, no need to move during this process, then there'll be the fussing and cleaning up, don't move. Wait for it, be patient, as soon as you hear the fridge door open that's when you make your move, it's turkey time. Timing is everything, as soon as the turkey hits the cutting board you start inching closer, a little whining helps, maybe inch in a bit more to where the drool lands on their slippers, that should be close enough. Don't make a move till the turkey comes out, Ancient Basset Saying.

The Warden decided I needed to go outside so she opened the back door, it was -10, with a biscuit in hand she stepped out onto the deck in her slippers and coaxed me out with the biscuit, then she said go pee. She ran back inside, went to the window to watch my every move but couldn't locate me, she started to panic and was bobbing from window to window, that's when she felt a chill, she looked over her shoulder and there I was, I had nudged the door open and returned with my biscuit. If she thinks I'm going out in that kind of weather she's crazier than I thought, I'll go when I gotta go, Ancient Basset Saying.

Not one hey hey from the cheap seats during this yank and drag while barking and The Warden didn't even post a warning about excessive barking which is a great sign that the recovery is going well and her tolerance level is still up. I'll yank that blanket off my lounger several times a day and skirt it around the room, of course I'll only do this when The Warden decides to sit and have a quiet moment, it is of course considered a spectator event and also helps build ab definition. Why do I always choose to do this when The Warden decides to have a quiet moment, it's so I can get her full attention and her eye starts to do a little shimmy. Create your own moments, don't wait for it to come to you, Ancient Basset Saying.

While out and about it sometimes takes a little extra time to select the perfect spot to do your business, it requires a lot of sniffing and there are times where you need to circle around a few times. If the final decision is on a busy four way street corner with lots of traffic, so be it, remain focused with your business at hand. Of course there are those that hold your leash who are not sure where to focus their attention, do they wave at passerby's or pretend to enjoy the scenery, not to worry not your problem, their responsibility is the final pickup while at the same time maintaining their dignity and telling you what a good girl you are.

Looking back I remember the first time I saw Shimmy Shaking Momma having a Proud Mary Moment, I initially thought it was a cry for help but was told this was normal and avoid eye contact. There's an old saying what happens in the family stays in the family, but that's not me, I thought it best to share as part of my healing process, some things you can't unsee. Thankfully with the restraining order she's not allowed to shimmy off premise but I didn't sign a non disclosure so I'm free to spill the beans. If tassels are involved maintain your distance in order to avoid any injuries, Ancient Basset Tip.

I saved the family, here's what happened. We were out on our walk and sniff when all of a sudden the hairs on the back of my neck stood up, I immediately braked and got in the attack position. Up ahead some unknown creature reared its ugly head, bouncing side to side while making guttural noises, I inched forward, took a stance and howled. Upon a closer look it turned out to be a tarp flapping in the wind, this time, never let your guard down, today a tarp tomorrow who knows what lurks in the shadows. We had to take a wide berth, I actually had to yank the family out of harms way, never tangle with a tarp, Ancient Basset Saying.

Every morning I get three gravy coated biscuits laid out beside my bowl of kibble, my first preference would be to bury the biscuit. Of course I must first get past security, one tip is to tuck it under your lip and then to act anxious like you have to pee, service becomes much quicker in this case. Once you're outside start looking for a burial site, if the ground is frozen pick a spot close to the fence, Ancient Basset Tip. Do not, I repeat, do not make eye contact with those penetrating eyes lurking through the window, they have issues and should be ignored. As a side note, for each biscuit you bury outside another one will take its place for you to eat or use when you do a biscuit dance.

What I remember of my dream. I was at the front door and I seized the moment and slipped past security, I was free and running up the street. I heard all this commotion and when I looked back I saw dad in his slippers chasing after me yelling cheese cheese, a small crowd had gathered cheering me on, they were all chanting cheese cheese. No one could catch me, I was bobbing and weaving, pulling out all my best moves until I realized the crowd wasn't just chanting cheese they were actually offering cheese, platters of it. Then everything took a dark turn, suddenly The Warden shows up, there was no cheese, she was standing there dangling my leash, wanting me to go back home, that's when I woke up, it was all just a cheese dream.

title: Untucking hospital corners is a great way to build ab definition (a close second is barking), like most professional athletes you have to train in perseverance, don't let one untucked corner hold you back. Keep in mind your ultimate goal, it's the yank and drag while barking, it's also a balancing act trying to keep the biscuit on the blanket as you yank it off the lounger. The audience has recently been upgraded from the cheap seats yelling hey hey to a crowd that loves my performance and looks on with great appreciation.  This is also an interactive sport where The Warden can participate by resetting the stage after I've completed the first round of the yank and drag while barking.

It's much more relaxed around here, yanking my blanket off the lounger is no big deal, The Warden just looks at me smiling. Maybe later on she'll tuck in my blanket with hospital corners just to watch me yank it off again or I'll get one of my gravy coated biscuits and bury it under the blanket, no problem, not even a hey hey. I've done a few yank and drag while barking and not a word from the cheap seats, maybe just maybe Shimmy Shaking Momma will once again crank up the music and have one of her Proud Mary Moments, that's when you'll know everything is right in my world.

media.title: How do you know recovery is going well, your chair gets stolen, this is a great moment. The pacing and frantic moments are gone, replaced with more napping and the occasional biscuit dance, nothing lifts the heart more than seeing her do a yank and drag while barking, music to my ears. We received great news, the cancerous lump that was removed needs no further treatment or follow up, we also decided to delay her teeth removal for a few months so she can completely recover from this surgery, she is not in distress from her teeth and we felt she needs more time to recover. I'm hoping in a few days she'll be back on the couch getting her ears rubbed and The Warden will be teetering on the edge clutching her evening juice.

Throwback to those quiet moments when The Warden and I would share the couch. It starts out with me at the end of the couch and The Warden stretched out with her slippers next to my head. Now comes the time where I need to stretch and rotate, that's also when I slither along side The Warden, easier access for her to rub my ear (helps calm her nerves). With some practice The Warden has learned the art of teetering on the edge while clutching her evening juice without spilling a drop. Sharing is caring, Ancient Basset Saying.

I've been given a new set of rules, don't wander in the deep snow, keep your belly dry, sounds reasonable until a scent catches your nose and it leads you into the deep unknown. Being a low rider and having defined abs covered in winter fluffiness you're bound to walk into a forbidden zone accidentally. Not to worry, The Warden is waiting at the door with a paper towel to pat dry any affected areas, of course a freshly warmed fluffy towel would be preferable but because she can't leave her lurking duties of watching me every second she's unable to accommodate my wishes.

All I could hear was this whispering, back and forth, I couldn't pick out any key words just mumbling, they weren't spelling out words but it was definitely covert activity. Apparently the vet called for an update and heard that I wasn't eating so it was decided I was to be given 'canned' food. The Warden had dad put it in my bowl then they stood there and looked at me, I developed a habit of not eating while being watched so they hid around the corner, still didn't work. That's when The Warden put a piece of cheese on top, I inched closer, smelled the food, grabbed the cheese off the top and realized there was gravy. With some privacy given I ended up eating all of the food and after The Warden cleaned up my gravy dippers, the cheese on top is a nice garnish to every meal.

title: Here's a sign I'm starting to feel better, while following The Warden around I noticed some things out of order, a few blankets scattered around the floor, well, they were piled neatly but somehow got moved. The Warden was also excited about me doing a biscuit dance, I did a yank and drag while barking with my gravy coated biscuit, the cheap seats actually applauded my performance, not a hey hey to be heard. The Warden has resumed her regular activities, while napping I can hear the hum of the vacuum and the constant clatter of fussing in the kitchen, of course the whole time stopping to peak in at me, I only peak in on her if I hear the fridge door open or it gets really quiet (she has tendencies to sneak snacks).

media.title: Finally the sweet sound of snoring after pacing most of the night, hopefully today Miss Lilly will return to her regular nap schedule and maybe do a yank and drag while barking. Now don't get me wrong, if I went to the fridge and quietly opened the cheese bag she would be front and centre waiting patiently for more than her share. It's exhausting and troubling to watch on helplessly while trying to offer comfort, maybe today she will eat her food or steal my chair or bark at me to chase her, let it be just a regular day where I can fix her lounger several times with hospital corners.

I'm usually a quiet slip of a girl but under certain circumstances I have to express myself, after surgery I was told to stay in the shoveled area to try and keep my belly dry, I considered that as option one. I'm under tight security, every step I take is being monitored and assessed but I did manage once to slip out of my dated dull t-shirt and I'm also allowed brief moments without the cone but only under the laser hawk eyes zeroed in on my every move. The Warden sends a huge thank you for your support, prayers and kind words, we will move forward with positive thoughts and be thankful for a speedy recovery.

title: Miss Lilly Update:  Three cysts and one cancerous lump on the belly was removed, plus the teeth were cleaned. The lump will be sent away for further testing and 5 teeth need to be removed in a few weeks. Yesterday was difficult, opening a bag of cheese and not to hear those thundering footsteps running to see who was sneaking snacks, when we brought her home she had some aged cheese, a piece of roast and a bowl of fresh filtered water with ice. Thank you all for your support, positive vibes and kind words, The Warden likes to respond to everyone but yesterday was overwhelming, it called for a little medicinal evening juice. Today is the first day on the road to recovery, The Warden will be watching over Miss Lilly and offering medicinal cheese on a need to please basis.

media.title: Today I'm scheduled to have my teeth cleaned and several lumps removed, The Warden may need to be sedated. I was on a restricted diet last night, no food after midnight, yes there goes my planned midnight snack of a small roast simmering in gravy followed by a platter of cheese. Now once this is over I am expecting some medicinal cheese and The Warden may also have to calm her nerves with a couple of medicinal evening juices. Today will be nothing but positive thoughts, bring me the funny, we will make the best of what comes our way, so please join us in a good vibe day.

The Warden took me outside to assess the weather situation, it's currently -15 and snow covered. Therefore soaking up the sun on the driveway is off the list of things to do today but barking at The Warden still remains a top contender. Even though it's a tad cold I still like to go outside and sniff each and every footprint in the snow, it keeps you informed about what is going on in the neighbourhood. Spending at least 15 minutes outside each day gives you that fresh linen smell that everyone loves, the colder it gets the fresher you smell, Ancient Basset Weather Tip.

What do you do when someone is giving you 'the look', it's simple, don't make eye contact. Every time I decide to do a yank and drag while barking, twice daily, I get 'the look' plus a few hey heys thrown in. It starts off with The Warden spreading the blanket on my lounger, tucking it in with hospital corners, then stepping back taking a deep breath knowing everything is in its place, that's about the time I show up and assess the situation. After a little excitement and entertainment you learn to appreciate the quiet moments, take a deep breath and relax.

Today we give thanks and remember those that have served our country, and for those that are currently serving so that we can live in peace and have our freedom, also a special thank you to my brother who currently serves in the Canadian Forces. We don't have to look too far to know how fortunate we are and the sacrifices others have made so we can enjoy living in a peaceful country that makes freedom possible. ð¨ð¦

title: Every morning while I'm having my first morning nap I start to hear the familiar hum of the vacuum, it's part of The Wardens daily therapy routine, it helps take the edge off so she can face the day. I'll lift my head sometimes or just roll back my eyes, she doesn't invade my space and I try to avoid her cleaning area, together we make a good team. As I gently glide through the house little sprinkles of glitter float everywhere and settle on the floor, thankfully this gives The Warden a purpose and it's also a good thing I'm just a slip of a girl who has a tendency to be a little fluffy, she needs me.

media.title: We had a pleasant surprise while out on our walk, I had my nose to the ground sniffing when suddenly a car veered over to our side of the street, the back seat window slowly rolled down and out popped the head of another Basset. It was an exciting moment, I started barking mixed with howling, I pulled out all my best moves, bobbing and weaving and still they all just stared at me. It's rare to see a Basset in our area, it turned out they were just passing through and spotted me sniffing. It was a brief moment but we found out his name was Charlie and he was handsome, not sure what he thought of me dancing around and barking at him, hopefully I left a lasting impression on him.

Well here it is, the first snow of the winter season and it's -7 so I'll make this first trip outside a quick one.  Now preparing to go outside is another story, you don't just rush out, you must first climatize in the doorway, safety first.  Here's how it went down, I was scratching at the door anxiously waiting to go outside, The Warden immediately came to my assistance, she opened the door and as the freezing air whipped around us I took a moment to sniff the air, I did a couple of extended stretches, each leg of course and eventually I meandered outside. The Warden was complaining about icicles hanging off her nose, lesson learned, dress appropriately if you're gonna stand in the doorway for extended periods of time during the winter season.

There are some things that need to be left alone, they're perfect just the way they are, you could sniff it out of a lineup, that would be my harness. The Warden decided to clean it and wash away a part of me, all my favourite smells just washed down the drain, she's actually quite proud of the results. She placed it in the sink, fills up with water to cover the harness, sprinkled it with baking soda, pours vinegar over it, swishes it around, then let's it soak for 20 minutes, rinses it off with clean water, pats it dry with a paper towel and finally hangs it up to dry. All I can say is I have my work cut out for me, first I have a bath and then my harness gets sanitized, this is what happens when you live with someone who has uncontrollable urges to clean, send cheese.

While out on my walk I like to spend a little extra time sniffing, you know, catching up on the neighbourhood news, I also like to add my own little tidbit, it's about staying connected to the community. After dropping a message I usually get the yank, a not so subtle message to get moving, apparently we don't have all day to meander. While strolling along, nose to the ground, I suddenly put the brakes on, well would you look at this, a dead worm on the sidewalk, talk about luck, I immediately went in for a dab on the neck, yes you guessed it, there was the yank and a flurry of hey heys. As a side note, if you hesitate you lose the moment of going home with a little dab of worm on your neck.

Warning:  content not suitable for everyone. While I was out and about in the backyard sniffing and checking for varmints I noticed that The Warden had suddenly become quite distressed and was using inappropriate language. She was doing her daily deposit pickups when she discovered the poop bag had a hole in the bottom and her hand became contaminated. You would've thought the sky was falling, there was a lot of garbled mumbling as she headed inside to the sanitization wing of the house (bathroom). Not to worry, after a good scrubbing using a nail brush, multiple times, she was as good as new, she might have a few flashbacks but a couple of evening juices will help with that.

The beginning of every day should start with a yank and drag while barking just to get everyone's blood flowing and eye twitching, it's a motivational tool. I personally like to wait until after brunch to ramp it up, just about the same time The Warden decides to have a quiet moment. It's all about balance, the mornings should be devoted to napping or as I refer to it as building ones strength for the days shenanigans. As a side note, your hearing becomes selective after your naps as the hey heys have a tendency to build throughout the day.

What happens when the time changes around here, everybody gets up at their regular time, they start chatting about the time change, every clock has to be turned back an hour, might as well start a load of laundry, all this knowing full well I'm trying to get my full compliment of sleep. Due to the flurry of activity I have to be somewhat engaged, somewhat, let's say just enough to hear if the fridge door opens. So the plan today is to get a few more naps in to make up for the time lost all because this household cannot seem to adapt to the slightest change, thank goodness I'm able to be the one to figure out what needs to be barked at and what doesn't.

Warning:  Some viewers may find this video disturbing, I've been violated, I was given a bath. The Warden is currently under house arrest and sentenced to the kitchen, I've suffered greatly by these savages who have no respect for my legal rights or bath schedule (my next bath was supposed to be in the summer of 2024). This horrific act was all about them, oh she's so soft, she smells so good, blah blah blah, it's the end of worm rolling season and this bath smell may linger for days or possibly weeks, haven't I suffered enough, no one will want to sniff me again, my reputation is destroyed.

I was given an A+ for my performance last night during the Halloween festivities, I didn't require Security to hold me back or to be tied up like a dog. When the door opened to greet kids I didn't bolt through the door or jump up on anyone, I politely kept my distance while dad handed out what was left of the chocolates (thankfully we didn't run out). Yes it could've been because of the heavy rain and wind storm that I choose to stay inside, that's one way of looking at the glass half empty or it could be that I've matured and was setting an example for others to aspire to. Thanks to all the kids who said 'hi Miss Lilly' even if I didn't recognize you in your costume, it was just great that everyone weathered the storm and stopped by for a visit.

Welcome to Barkville, the home of Little Miss Lilly, who will be greeting all tricker treaters tonight, be afraid be very afraid, there will be barking, scratching at the door and attempts will be made to jump up on those who don't come armed with cheese. Security will be posted at the door but enter at your own risk, treats will be given out to those who are brave enough to enter into the chaos. Come one come all but come early, it appears that the Security Staff are enjoying the treats and The Warden is worried about the supplies holding up, but not to worry I have lots of kibble I can share. Happy Halloween my friends.

I like to be supportive and give encouragement to all those that do physical and manual labour, I appreciate your efforts and would like to offer you a cheese platter while we celebrate your achievements. I personally look at work or manual labour as a spectator event but that's just me, it's not for everyone. We all have goals and aspirations, mine is celebrating your accomplishments with a small roast simmering in gravy while you babble on about how you got here through hard work, motivation and sacrifice. As a side note, where would you be without me cheering you on (barking at you) and giving you an ear to caress.

Worm rolling season is coming to an end so I'm taking advantage of several last rolls. To get the full affect of a worm roll make sure you thrust your back legs and wiggle around, that way any worm remnants can be embedded into your back for that long lingering scent. You will be the envy of all on your walks as others crowd around you for a sniff, don't be put off if there are those who don't find you sniff worthy, ignore them they probably have issues. I personally don't have to worry about a bath as my next bath is currently scheduled in the summer of 2023, unless of course I get caught in the rain again, that'll push the date to the spring of 2024, as a side note, it's illegal to give baths during the winter season.

How to get attention when you're feeling neglected, here's one way to get their eye twitching. First off you enter the room, look around for a target which in this case was the throw on the back of The Wardens chair. Next you stand up against the side of the chair, brace yourself then grab onto the dangling throw and start yanking. Once the throw starts moving plant yourself on all fours and keep tugging, before you know it you'll be doing a yank and drag while barking, just keep skirting that throw all over the floor. That's about the time you hear the hey heys and a few other choice words, depending on their tolerance level you may even get a small morsel of medicinal cheese, it helps calm down the situation.

Something terrible just happened, beyond words, so let me paint you a picture. I woke up early, it was still dark outside and nature was calling so I headed straight for the backdoor, The Warden came running as one does when I scratch at the door and that's when I realized it was pouring buckets of rain. I hesitated, looked up at The Warden, who was of no help, that's when I realized this was a solo journey. After what seemed like forever I came back inside, the staff was ready with a paper towel rub down, a warm towel would've been my preference but I excepted the rub down and was given a special treat for enduring this horrific experience. As a side note, this counts as a bath, my next official bath is now scheduled for the summer of 2023, that's the good news.

title: A lot has changed in 5 years, what hasn't changed is I'm still sitting in the same chair looking out the same window waiting for company to stop by. The aged cheese is still on the second shelf in the fridge and I still have to beg for even a morsel. My yank and drag while barking is still a fan favourite especially when I dance around with a gravy coated biscuit on it. The Warden still has issues but we ignore her while she cleans, she gets lots of attention while cooking a roast simmering in gravy and I lay with her each evening on the couch while she has a quiet moment with her evening juices. I'm one lucky slip of a girl surrounded by a family who is giving me the best life possible.

media.title: There I was in the zone, snoozing, when all of a sudden I heard the crinkling of a bag, not sure if it was the cheese bag but I'm not taking any chances. It's a distinctive sound, first there's the pitter patter of footsteps in the kitchen, fussing around and cleaning (after awhile you block out those noises) but when the fridge door opens you start to focus and zero in on each movement. It's not worth the effort if it's fruit or veggies so I wait, when The Warden opens the cheese bag she tries to conceal the sound which in itself a dead giveaway, ever so slowly she tries to slide open the baggie, I can hear each popping sound, that's when I make my move.  It's important to be sitting and staring at her at the exact same moment the cheese slice is released from the bag.

Throwback to the attack of the furminator, it was done with style and grace, my barking was like a gentle whisper in the breeze, just loud enough to stay under the radar of the neighbourhood noise authorities but not quiet enough for The Warden who has noise issues, I received a couple of hey heys which I didn't hear because I was barking. The furminator on the other hand suffered a few bite marks, nothing that will impede a good brushing, actually it makes for a better grip and it now has some character with a story to tell.

It's important to maintain a regular fitness routine, these abs don't define themselves. You may be saying quietly and politely to yourself 'what ab definition', well I'm in a relaxed mode, it's important to rest your abs, that's why getting lots of naps enhances your fitness level. I might also point out that with the winter season approaching I'm naturally developing an extra layer of fluffiness, it's a technical term for belly flaps, isn't nature wonderful. As a side note, the constant pursuit of cheese is considered exercise, it's along the same line as planking.

Does the sound of barking travel during a heavy wind warning and if it does is there an emergency alert sent out to the neighbourhood watch, these are thoughts that travel through the mind of someone with too much time on their hands (who also has issues). Imagine my barking traveling through the breeze and being picked up by a neighbour, they're probably saying 'listen everyone, it's Miss Lilly having some fun and barking at The Warden'. If I do bark it's usually after brunch or if I'm bored and require some much needed attention, there's a small window of barking opportunities during my day because I'm either sleeping, napping or in the pursuit of cheese.

Decisions decisions, do I hover in the shadows and wait for The Warden to make a move towards the fridge or do I attempt a break and enter through the barrier and bark at Contractor Tim. It's a rare sighting these days when The Warden reaches for the aged cheese on the second shelf, I can't afford to miss out on this possibility but there's my favourite guy in the front room waiting for me to bark at the fireplace. I do have a cheese deficiency so I have to consider my health and well-being, I've been barking a lot lately which is one of the symptoms that my cheese levels are low. Of course I could break through the barrier and start barking which will make The Warden come running in with medicinal cheese, looks like option three is a winner.

The Warden had a friend stop by for a visit, she greeted me by saying 'hello dog', I mean really, that's the best you can come up with 'hello dog'. Clearly this was not a fur-family person but that didn't stop me from being receptive, although I did hold back from jumping up on her, I instinctively knew she wouldn't appreciate the full on knock 'em down brace yourself greeting, so I just laid on her feet. She was also wearing black tights with a beautiful black coat and by the time she left she was covered in Basset glitter, a gift that just keeps on giving.

I'm issuing a warning to all predators who violate what is now known as the barren wasteland (formally known as the urban jungle), move along, this is my stomping grounds.  Even if you can't see me, we'll see you (I'm never alone), The Warden has night vision goggles, don't ask, it's my reality. I could just be sniffing around catching up on the news when all of a sudden I'll look up and there's these beady eyes following my every move, have you ever heard the phrase, get a life, she's needy with issues, that's my reality.

No judgement please, live and let live, I'm not your fancy slip of a girl, I'm just me, living my best life. Do I bark, yes, do I beg and whine, that's a given, do I require endless amounts of attention, it's what I deserve but I also work for it. I'm practically maintenance free, I don't need to have baths, I'm just naturally clean, no need to make extravagant meals, just open the fridge and there on the second shelf is the aged cheese in a handy bag, easy, no fuss. Of course I'm open to being served a small roast simmering in gravy but who wouldn't be, gotta put those gravy dippers to good use.

title: I like to be involved in activities that are inclusive, where I can participate and feel like I'm contributing. For example, raking leaves is fun only if the other person is not worried about picking up every single leaf, who cares if I'm laying on a few, also with the wind blowing if I laid here any longer I'd be covered in leaves. It's a time for running around and barking, especially if you can run through a pile of leaves, love how they scatter all over, I wasn't quite sure if the hey heys were directed at the barking or the leaves, doesn't matter when you're having a good time.

Breaking News, the wildlife authorities have been called in at the request of a distressed local resident who is currently under the care of the first responders at the scene. It appears that the extraction may take longer than expected as the main attraction currently is Miss Lilly who requires some attention from all responders. After a stream of babbling it appears that The Warden was attempting to wash a window when she discovered a massive creature hovering in a threatening manner, we just received word that she is resting comfortably and will soon be allowed visitors (if you are unable to visit a cheese basket would be greatly appreciated).

If you can believe it I got blocked from going into the construction site, Contractor Tim is working on the fireplace and I got banned for excessive barking.  Trust me it was a bark-able moment, there was a drill, a measuring tape, tiles, a mantle, I was left with no choice but to bark. It didn't take long before The Warden showed up, she was like a drill sergeant ordering everyone around and she quickly marched me out of the room and created a barrier. I definitely told her what I thought of the whole situation, thankfully Contractor Tim took some time to console me, he clearly sees and understands what I'm having to deal with.

media.title: Today we give thanks to all the little things that sometimes go unnoticed. All those walks we go on as a family and letting me have the extra time to sniff, not yanking my leash every time I discover something to roll on and dropping everything you're doing just to give me a little attention and telling me I'm a good girl. You don't always have to say how much you love me, I know, when I open my eyes you are watching over me and when I settle in for a nap you are there. Happy Thanksgiving to all my friends, may you all be as blessed as we are.

I got to experience my first ever yard sale on our street, cars were parked all over, people were coming and going, there was excitement in the air and I was ready to mingle. Except for one problem, nobody was stopping by to visit me, I pulled out all the stops, I did a little running around bobbing and weaving, I rolled on a worm, I got nothing, so I finally had to bark. Well that got some attention from The Warden, she was trying to be polite and act lady like while she quietly issued a few hey heys, I just ramped it up until she finally said we had to go inside. As a side note, yard sales would be more profitable if they offered cheese and invited the neighbours, just a suggestion for next time.

I'm trying to convince The Warden that she needs a special drool moisturizer for her hands, all she has to do is give me a chin rub. While she's doing that she might as well slip on down to the neck and over to the ear, there's enough moisturizer to do both hands and probably your feet, just keep on rubbing. Instead of wiping your hands on a tissue or your clothes and without making noises about icky stuff just take advantage of what nature has to offer, there's plenty of drool and you need all the help you can get.

When you're just a slip of a girl you sometimes worry that you won't get noticed, so I make myself available and just wait for the attention to flow my way. Yes there are times when you have to go to extreme measures and it may take a little extra effort but you do what works, you bark. A sure way that almost guarantees is to do a yank and drag while barking, this gets you an audience who appreciates your creativity. Don't worry about the eye twitching or the hey heys, it's just temporary and after several minutes of an ear rub they calm down, it's a win win.

Throwback to the day I sneaked into the wine cellar and was able to yank The Wardens housecoat off it's hanger, which created a whole series of events. I yanked so hard the top shelf broke away from the wall, the antique iron flew off the shelf and somehow I managed to escape without any injuries. The Warden was the first responder to the scene of the crime, she was happy to report there was no damage to the wine (or me) but the closet shelf needed repair. The Warden had to remove all the clothes from the closet in order to repair the damage but she did let me have the housecoat so I could do a yank and drag while barking. Since this incident the housecoat has never been seen again and the wine cellar is considered off limits.

title: Do not call the authorities, while rolling on a worm I stretched beyond the limit of my carefully measured line, there was a slight yank but I just stood up and shook it off.  Meanwhile while I'm capturing the end of the worm rolling season The Warden is ripping out the flowers in the front garden, at least until she encountered a spider, that put a halt to all activity, she's hoping with the frost overnight all creepy crawlers will head underground or wherever they go to hibernate for winter. Thankfully the neighbours were spared from witnessing a spider scene of flapping and slapping, their focus should be only on me and not someone with icky issues.

media.title: I was just sniffing and meandering out front in the driveway when finally someone showed up, they went to the neighbours but company is company. It was the mail lady and she came running across the street to fuss over me even though she's allergic to dogs, she said it was worth it. Remember the day I got loose and was running around having a grand old time, The Warden was having a meltdown and the mail lady was chasing after me yelling cheese cheese. It was a fun time being chased around and as soon as I saw The Warden flapping around with cheese I immediately ran home, it was a moment where everyone bonded together, the moral of this story is cheese saves lives, when in doubt serve cheese.

Let's start off the week by easing up on the rules, try your best to ignore the small infractions that get you riled up, it's Monday and I need time to adjust to the beginning of another week. When The Warden sees that I've made a slight adjustment to the neatly tucked in blanket she starts to get fidgety and is mentally putting this on her list of things to do. Well I have a list of things that she can do, first off back up and let me ease into the day, secondly there's some aged cheese on the second shelf in the fridge that's calling my name, it would be the right thing to do if you could get that for me, thank you in advance for your thoughtfulness and kindness, much appreciated.

I have a personal request from The Warden to do all my business in an area not littered with leaves, there's no harm in asking but it's not an achievable goal. When I'm on my business turf the last thing I'm thinking about is a non leafy area so your request while not practical has been denied. There is a solution though it may require a little work each day in order to prepare the yard as 'business ready' and it's called raking the leaves. The backyard yard leaves (from the neighbours tree I might add) are brown and curled in shape which gives the appearance of ones business, Mother Nature does has a sense of humour.

Not every yank and drag while barking is a success, while trying to yank the blanket off my lounger I ran into a bit of a snag (hospital corner), I also ran out of energy and was unable to complete my mission. Not to worry, after a brief nap I had those blankets twirling around the room and was barking up a storm. That's also about the time The Warden stepped in with the hey heys and attempted to yank the blankets away from me, we had a bit of a tug-of-war until she realized I had my feet planted and was in it to win it. Yes, I won and The Warden didn't, another hard fought win for Team Lilly.

I got in a bit of trouble, there was a couple of hey heys and The Warden threatened to take me inside if I didn't comply with the noise violation (I barked). Here's what happened, I was sniffing around, it was cold, no warm sun, The Warden was raking leaves and I got bored so I barked. The focus of my barking was at The Warden who quietly issued some colourful language, which by the way doesn't work, so she tried to distract me by asking me nonsensical questions, so I continued barking. The Warden quickly picked up the last leaf and marched me inside (another win for me), she also refuses to look back at where she just finished working, the wind was blowing and the lawn was once again covered in leaves.

Throwback to the time I made a public service announcement about making all fridges accessible, I stand behind this statement. It's time we all come together and do the right thing, get rid of all barriers and free the cheese. Speaking from personal experience, who is currently suffering from a cheese deficiency, let's take this to the streets and howl for change. We can no longer suffer in silence, we must demand change and direct access to the finest aged cheese (located on the second shelf), a small contribution would be greatly appreciated towards this worthy cause #misslillyfreesthecheese

title: There was a slight delay in the total destruction of the urban jungle, The Warden had to take a break after the spider incident. One hosta plant remains until the colder weather sets in so that there's no chance of any creepy crawly icky things to attack innocent people or drama queens. I don't mind, it still gives me plenty of room to soak up the sun or bury my biscuits before the snow comes. This break from completing a job shows how traumatized The Warden was from being attacked by a spider, lesson learned, wear a hair net.

media.title: Here we are once again when The Warden gets out the gardening tools and totally destroys the urban jungle. This is my final stroll through the deep dark underbelly of the only oasis I have from the constant surveillance cameras. The only thing that's currently under the plants right now are a few spiders, so buckle up as The Warden goes in without a hair net and breaks through the spiderwebs. As a side note if you do get tangled up in a spiderweb the best thing to do is roll around on the grass, do not, I repeat, do not run around slapping yourself like you're on fire, the only thing this does is make you look like a fool.

There should be a rule about the movement of the household staff on a Monday morning, slow down, at least until brunch. My Monday motivation is stuck and your attention to detail is bothering me, so park it or move to the kitchen and be productive. Why do they find it necessary to constantly clean, studies have shown that this behaviour bothers us, it disrupts our naps, we have to nap with one eye open and listen to every move you make, give us a break and knock it off.

Every move you make every snack you take I'll be watching you, closely. Positioning is everything while you're watching their every move, of course being comfortable is essential if they're trying to do it on the sly. For example, the Warden is sneaky, while she's fussing in the kitchen and turns her back to you and suddenly disappears below counter level, she's either picking up something or taking a bite of a snack, she has a reputation of shady behaviour so assume she's eating something, that's when you make your move. Try to make a sudden appearance while they're out of sight, the shock value alone will make them hand over the goods.

Yes when I see danger or something different or new, I bark, it's a warning to the family to be on high alert and they better come running. The dryer door was left open and there was a foreign substance inside, alright it was a towel, this time. This raises all kinds of questions about what the staff are doing, besides wasting energy and my time. Fortunately The Warden was the first responder at the scene and was able to save the towel and close the dryer door.  Today we righted a wrong, hopefully a valuable lesson was learned from this incident and we can go forward with making better use of our time either in the kitchen or napping.

Here I am out in the wilderness all by myself, all I can hear is the gentle breeze whispering my name, oh wait, that's The Warden constantly reminding me not to wander away. Actually I'm ignoring her, with my new found freedom I'm keeping my nose to the ground and discovering what wildlife has pasted through the area. It's rather distracting to hear heavy breathing and someone muttering while I'm on the hunt, it sort of takes away the element of surprise if there was a varmint who's brave enough to stay within the vicinity of The Warden, she has that effect on wildlife and people, did I happen to mention she has issues.

Throwback to the good ole days, remember them, when all I had to do was bark at nothing and get rewarded with cheese. Of course The Wardens famous last words, I don't reward bad behaviour but I make an exception if it works in the moment, that's when her nerves are frayed. Nowadays, being denied all the day to day comforts of any treats or fridge related foods, The Warden has to change her strategy for the easy fix, now when I bark she must drop everything she's doing and give me her undivided attention, which I deserve, of course I also get a few hey heys but that goes without saying. As a side note I must say we are getting a lot of quality time together now, lesson learned, bark and get the attention you so deserve.

Now I ask you, does my barking/howling require a hey hey, it certainly doesn't rise to the level of disturbing the peace. It's like greeting a neighbour, just saying hi, how you doing, would you like to come over and share a platter of cheese, of course this example was of someone who totally ignored me (no cheese for him). Most people are more cordial and will make the effort to come over and acknowledge my presence, maybe this guy was having a long day or he doesn't understand that Bassets require a more formal greeting.

On this #tot I present to you a rare sighting these days, a gravy coated biscuit, someone at the top of the food chain decided to ration my biscuits in order to enhance my taste for kibble, in other words they are starving me. It's becoming a faint memory now but I haven't had any real food in over a week, except for, wait for it, the weak link slipped me a tiny piece of ham. Under the harsh lights during an interrogation dad made a full confession to the ham incident, the only thing worse than the harsh lights under interrogation is the twitching eye glare. The Warden firmly believes that the ham incident increased my expectations as I forlornly gazed into her eyes willing her to weaken and go to the fridge.

And so I begin another week, just me and the crickets, waiting for someone to stop by and acknowledge my existence. Maybe if I'm lucky a delivery truck will make it's way onto our street, that's when all the action starts, I'll mosey to the end of the driveway and wait, I'll howl in case they don't see me, which will only alert security who are quick with the hey heys. For heaven sake, there's no one around to care about me howling, what's the big deal, this is what happens when you live with someone who has self esteem issues and are always looking for attention, fortunately I don't have that problem.

Someone said I had 'dog breath' which I found offensive and slanderous. If the essence of my breath has changed it's because I'm being forced to eat kibble and everyone knows that dog food has an offensive odor. There seemed to be no problem when I was eating roast simmering in gravy or aged cheese so if we look at the evidence presented it's the kibble that's the problem. Today would be a great day for a roast simmering in gravy and a platter of cheese, that way you wouldn't need to scrunch up your nose and say unkind things, it's about doing the right thing, be kind to others and offer cheese.

I'm being denied access to my lounger, call the authorities (again). So here's what happened, Contractor Tim stopped by to do some work on the fireplace mantel and he pulled out the measuring tape which started a round of barking, that got me banned from the room. Well, I also barked at the mantle but who wouldn't, never seen it before and it needed to be barked at. So The Warden came up with the idea of blocking access to the room, my barking rights have been violated, apparently her nerves are frayed and her tolerance level has hit rock bottom. What ever happened to the good ole days where you solved your problem with a piece of cheese, it's a well known fact that medicinal cheese has a calming effect.

title: Keep them guessing, build the suspense, if you hear someone calling your name it probably means they want you back inside, simply put, ignore them. Of course there's always exceptions to this rule, if they are yelling cheese cheese, run like hell, same thing applies if company arrives but if it's just because they have control issues and a schedule then you can apply the selective hearing clause of the Basset Handbook. It's also fun to get them riled up, they start to offer up all kinds of incentives, maybe they'll come stomping out in their slippers trying to herd you inside while you're ducking and weaving all over the yard, yes this is pure entertainment, arms flailing all over, colourful language and let's not forget the ever popular twitching eye.

media.title: Throwback to the day The Warden lost sight of me in the backyard only to discover I had jumped in the window well. As you can imagine this turned into a crisis situation, a recovery team was assembled, The Warden instructed that I be airlifted out of the danger zone, the predator was to be captured and relocated to another city, fortunately the first responders didn't need to resuscitate any bystanders, they just gave her a paper bag to breathe into. The adrenaline was pumping that day, I came back to that window well many times looking for the little visitor that created a day worth remembering.

It's almost the end of worm rolling season so take a few moments each day before the frost sets in and get your roll on. Embrace your worm roll, wiggle around and let this become your signature scent, others will enjoy sniffing you, you'll be the envy of the neighbourhood. Don't focus on the naysayers who like to dampen the party, who are always quick with the hey heys, keep your nose to the ground and continue your search for the elusive worm smell. As a side note, if the worms are getting harder to sniff out feel free to roll on an alternate smelly substance, it's a personal choice.

I don't know if you can tell but I have a cheese deficiency unlike anything in recorded history, it's been four days without cheese. A small roast simmering in gravy has become nothing but a faint memory, my gravy dippers hang dry and uncrusted with no one chasing me around with a wet cloth, the good ole days. In my weakened state I no longer scratch the treat cabinet, the cupboards are bare, I'm fading away to a shadow of myself. Being just a slip of a girl I have to be mindful in the fall season that I don't get blown away like the leaves. As a side note I'm eating my kibble and my system seems to be back on track (they seem to be excited about picking up firm poop).

It's a windy day so I'm taking cover in the urban jungle, I can't chance getting blown away, that's what happens when you're just a slip of a girl.  Also The Warden saw a sky predator hovering over the backyard sizing me up, that's when she yelled 'she's heavier than she looks'. If the truth be told it was probably eyeing up The Warden and good luck trying to airlift her out, you'd need more than two talons you'd need a crane.

If you are reading this please notify the authorities, I'm weak from hunger, I'm being deprived of my basic daily requirements of sustenance, my cheese deficiency has set an all time high. They've taken away all my treats and the kitchen is no longer serving a small roast simmering in gravy, who are these people. Their theory is I will eventually eat my new kibble, if I have the strength to drag myself to my dish, well, I did manage in my weakened state to try a small portion, I was left with no other alternative. This is total BS to be put on the road to making wiser lifestyle choices (hopefully better bowel movements and to avoid a trip to the vet).

Some may think eating a gravy coated biscuit is pretty straight forward but I beg to differ, with each biscuit you must set the stage. With this particular biscuit I simulated a burial process, digging into my lounger until I ruffed up the blanket, because of the hospital corners I was unable to cover up the biscuit. It's about learning to adapt to your situation along the way, now that you've moistened the biscuit, set it down and savour the anticipation, never feel rushed even if you're getting glares from the cheap seats. They are probably focused on the other blanket that was previously used for a yank and drag while barking, I'm building their anticipation of when they can re-tuck both blankets on my lounger, I'll make them wait.

As I was strolling through the park I noticed another little dog unharnessed and playing fetch with a ball, imagine running free with no restraints, he was totally focused on the ball running back and forth actually playing fetch. I on the other hand am in a harness and on a short sturdy leash, which is used for maximum control, did I happen to mention they have control issues. Enough about my leash problems, I was able to meet the little dog but only briefly, he had to be leashed when we met because he can be aggressive, so we did a quick sniff exchange and then he went back to his fetching and I continued on with my walk and sniff.

title: Throwback to the time when you recognized that someone was in need and you offered an ear, something to caress and calm the nerves. If you notice the signs of a twitching eye, hovering tendencies or excessive cleaning it could be a sign that the nerves are frayed and they need a moment of quiet and tranquility. It's a small thing that can lead to big rewards, after a session of calming therapy they start to feel more generous and giving which is good for the soul, hopefully they feel inspired to get up and go to the fridge for some cheese, it's a win win for everyone.

media.title: Not everything goes according to plan but never let that stop you from trying. My yank and drag while barking was hindered due to the hospital corners, as you can tell The Wardens broken wing is on the mend, we are now a two blanket tuck. I'm also placing bets that very few noticed the tad of slobber left on the fireplace as I grazed past, but you know who did, yeah that's right, someone with a whole lot of issues. Not to worry the cleanup staff came rushing in to re-tuck the blankets, adjust the lounger and wipe up any excess slobber, this is all part of their therapy which helps them sleep at night.

title: Trust me I did not wander through the flowers, security was tight and hovering in the background. Of course when a delivery guy stopped by and offered me a treat I immediately buried it in the forbidden sacred garden (disclaimer: no flowers were damaged), The Warden was being polite and didn't want to yell hey hey in front of the young man. It would probably unnerve most people but I've become immune to these outbursts, it's like an annoying pesky fly you just bat away.
