I was given a new menu which turned out to be great, I actually ate everything in my dish and took one large kibble to my blanket for a biscuit dance. The Warden held her breath the whole time and after the examination the Doc said I was a beautiful girl and all was good.

media.title: Throwback to when we had a guest who thought they could stretch out on my couch, oh go ahead but know you're on my turf. With one good stretch and rotate you might have to bend those knees and start making a little more room, I know I'm just a slip of a girl but I need a little more breathing room. Also at the end of the evening The Warden will hand out a complimentary wet cloth to help remove any slobber and hair, as always all guests are welcome.

There was a bit of excitement around here, while outside I found a buried biscuit and decided to bring it inside, you would've thought it was a dead animal by all the fuss, it was covered in a little dirt, get a grip. I dropped the biscuit on my blanket getting ready to do a biscuit dance when The Warden swooped in snatched the biscuit and replaced it with a fresh biscuit. It took the wind out of my sails, I lost the pep in my step, who wants to dance with a substitute biscuit.

Your gravy coated biscuit sticks nicely to the blanket once it has been moistened, now it's time to shake your booty. A little back and forth tippy toe, it's called free styling, just do your thing and of course you can't help but sing (bark). The biscuit dance is an ancient Basset tradition, in the early years it may not have been gravy coated but just a plain nugget, doesn't matter, it's all about the expressive dance moves. Just feel the energy, the momentum, the eye twitching, oh to dance like everyone's watching.

I don't like getting wet and I don't like Monday's, I felt it was important that I take a stand and let you know how I felt. While doing any protest make sure you take a peek to make sure you have their attention, otherwise what's the point in wasting energy. This was a four blanket uprise, I heard a couple of hey heys but it wasn't enough to distract me from making a statement. I think overall my message was sent and received.

Adjusting to the time change is not an easy transition, adjusting to any change can definitely upset the apple cart. So to help you through this difficult time I have a few pointers, the most important advice I can offer would be to extend all naps today by ten minutes. After each nap you should have a small piece of cheese, this helps with the realignment of the day. I'm only suggesting a small piece of cheese (preferably aged cheese) due to all the naps you'll need for this adjustment process. Finally and most importantly, according to all the experts, end the day with a large serving of roast simmering in gravy, then let your gravy dippers do their thing.

Oops I did it again, one more biscuit buried and it feels so good. Never ever linger after a successful burial, it'll only draw unwanted attention, just walk away like it's just another day. The Warden was busy raking leaves so she didn't notice and I don't worry about the surveillance cameras, by the time they're reviewed it's after the fact, what can they do.

Come on out they said, we'll go for a short walk, we won't get wet, it'll be fun, well I got wet and it wasn't fun. Oh what family fun we had together as I got patted down with a paper towel, humiliating and downright cruel. Two things are to be noted, first, this is considered a bath so you can forget about your proposed bath next summer, it's off the schedule. Secondly, you have now officially been served, we're going to court.

Throwback to yesterday when The Warden was getting ready for Howloween, she didn't want the kids tripping over the little ugly fences or she was trying to avoid a lawsuit. It was a successful night, I was shackled with my harness and leash, there was no jumping up on kids, I got a piece of cheese for being on my best behaviour and dad scored with all the leftover treats.

It was a dark eerie night with ghosts and goblins floating around, bats hovering over my head and the anticipation of little ones lining up at the door for trick or treat. I have received special instructions for tonight, no barking, no jumping, I must be tethered on a leash so I don't escape amongst all the kids. The Warden has come up with a plan, she'll be the one holding the leash and every time someone comes to the door she'll offer me a piece of cheese (one of her better plans).

It's Tomfoolery Tippy-toe Tuesday, any time you see a blanket draped over someone take advantage of the moment, drop your biscuit and let the dance begin. The crowd is going wild, chanting hey heys, I'm stepping up my game, everyone is enjoying the show and I will not disappoint. Just ignore the heckling from the back row, they're just jealous that their interpretive expression of dance has been getting bad reviews (for years).

As a reminder after every strenuous workout be sure to take the time to recoup and recover, that's what Monday's are for, so today I'm gathering my strength. You know you're in a relaxed state when you can't see the definition of your abs and your muscles of steel are laying unclenched. Those around you should respect your recovery time, they should try to minimize all movements unless of course it's in the kitchen.

A little fun day Sunday, doing a little yank and drag, some untucking of hospital corners and all this accompanied by barking, this should stir up a few hey heys. It's a rainy day with the possibility of snow showers so I'll have to consider some indoor activities (in between naps of course). While I'm making good use of my time and setting an example maybe someone else could be creative and spend a little quality time in the kitchen, good day for a roast simmering in gravy, just putting it out there!

I might've got in a tad bit of trouble, The Warden has no tolerance for barking outside or else she's afraid the authorities will be called in to investigate a case of neglect. Now that the colder weather is here I can't spend my time soaking up the sun, so why can't someone spend every minute devoted to me, chase me until I stop or call me over for constant fussing until I'm ready to go in, why oh why.

It's biscuit burying Friday, slipped past security and managed to get a biscuit outside. The burial sites are a dime a dozen now that the garden is a barren wasteland, just make sure you've buried it deep enough so the critters scavenging for winter bounty don't snatch this up. Also there's on going maintenance happening by The Warden who's obsessed with raking leaves so make sure you don't get lazy and try to bury under the leaves (been there done that).

title: Throwback to my baby days, when I first came home I had a list of rules to follow, no getting on the furniture, must eat only prescribed dog food, had a pee schedule for outside, no chewing on the furniture, has to sleep in a cage and must be trained to obey commands. Well they had good intentions, I was their first four legged fur family member, within a few days I was sleeping on the bed at night, during the daytime I was being helped up on the couch and chairs (whenever I wanted), the wood furniture still has signs of chewing, I've become a connoisseur of aged cheese and roast with gravy, I've developed selective hearing and the good news is I do my business outside whenever nature calls. I'm one of the lucky ones that found a home full of love â¤ï¸

media.title: I smell squirrel in the air with just a hint of chipmunk, it's a beehive of activity with all the creatures getting ready for winter. There was also an extremely large black bird in the trees with talons big enough to pick up a sizeable prey, The Warden is concerned and keeping a watchful eye on this predator. She thought if she yelled out 'she's heavier than she looks so don't even think about it' that this might detour any attempts to swoop in for a quick pick up, I'm not sure how I feel about that comment.

In a perfect world there would be no little ugly fences between these bushes, let me rephrase that, in a perfect world there would be no line attached to my collar. The Warden doesn't like me to get tangled up around the bushes, well, unhook the line, release the hounds, I promise to stay within the property line. Unless of course I see someone or there's something moving or a delivery person or a tantalizing scent, other than that I'll be sticking pretty close to the property line.

title: Just had all my blankets washed, they were meticulously tucked in and around my lounger, then The Warden stood back and appraised her work, a job well done, that's about the time I showed up. I assessed the situation, the blankets had a clean smell, no biscuit crumbs, not a hair in sight, hospital corners in tact, a clean slate, I had my work cut out for me. After a few yanks and pulls I had the top two blankets taken care of, I was also getting the 'look' so I guess my job is done for now but I'll be back.

media.title: This time my barking was warranted, I spotted a fly on the house, therefore an alarm was issued. It may seem like a small annoyance but if you let this pass then I wonder what else gets by. I have an important job to do, looking for what potentially could be threats to the family, I should've received a 'good girl' not a 'hey hey'. As a side note, I couldn't get any closer because of the little ugly fences.

The Warden kept tossing me things to keep me occupied so I wouldn't bark, there was my furminator (hair brush), broom, dustpan, hand brush, mitten and small clippers. She also decided to get the snowblower out and dusted (covered in hair), I pranced around it, pawed at the ground and started howling, shortly after this we went inside. Any time you move, change or rearrange anything it becomes open season on howling, what did she expect when she pulled out the snowblower.

Flashback Friday because The Warden is still having flashbacks. There was a mouse running around the fireplace and I was following his every move, my adrenaline was at an all time high, then out of nowhere in swoops The Warden with a poop bag on her hand, she grabs the mouse by the leg, heads for the door and flings the mouse outside. I immediately ran outside, nose down ready to track the predator but lost precious time trying to pick up a scent and the mouse escaped. First aid responders were called in to assist with The Warden, we're expecting a full recovery, eventually.

Throwback to the final destruction of the backyard, The Warden can now put her clippers away and get the shovel ready. There will of course be leaves to rake up because there's nothing worse than searching through leaves looking for the daily deposit, according to The Warden. There was a dead frog found on the lawn which was quickly scooped up and bagged, so I was denied a closeup inspection or the possibility of a roll (she has eyes like a hawk).

The Warden made me come inside due to excessive barking, it was quiet on the street, no one in sight and she was worried about a tiny bit of noise. She said nobody wants to hear that noise, well there was no one around, what's the big deal. As a side note I have received no complaints about a noise disturbance and I might add I do not have a restraining order issued against me, so I can freely bark in public unlike someone else who can't shimmy in public, just telling it like it is.

Every day there's a new challenge, how do I get a real treat (high end treat, something from the fridge) or a little extra love'n (constant rubs, scratches and sweet talking). Sometimes it's like climbing a mountain (short legs) or going up against a giant (The Warden), the struggle is real, I'm usually not one to beg but if I have to I will, maybe I'll even bark, whatever it takes you can count on me.

Does a blanket over your head muffle the annoying bark, that was the pondering question by The Warden on a Monday morning. If your head was completely buried it might muffle the sound a tad but you don't get the same riled up results. If you're gonna do something then do it to the best of your ability, don't put a muffler on it, bark loud and proud, you be you, this pondering moment was brought to you by Miss Lilly.

Not mentioning any names but someone said I stunk, I find that offensive, yes there may be a slight odor but with excessive rolling on smelly stuff that's to be expected. I personally think someone has severe issues with smells, it does not make your eyes water or cause you to wrinkle your nose, well yes in your case maybe it does but it could be about time you dealt with your nose sensitivity issues, just saying.

There are ways to get extra attention but you have to be selective about the precise moment. Now I personally wait until after a busy day when everyone is settling in getting ready to read and relax, perfect timing, their resistance is low. They're looking at you (you've got their attention), now it's decision time, do I get the call to come over because they realize I'm being neglected or do they just go get the cheese, decisions decisions.

title: We've moved on to the front yard and the clipper happy Warden has yanked out one section of flowers and chopped off the blood grass, now she wants me out of the garden.  This is the perfect time to be in the garden, instead of people commenting on the flowers they could notice me front and center, how unique to have a basset displayed in your garden. Warning issued, if you get too close this nicely displayed basset will bark and jump up so brace yourself.

Throwback to a few days ago when The Warden completely destroyed the urban jungle, it's now a barren wasteland. No biscuit were recovered during this archeological dig, there were lots of spiders and worms which is why The Warden wore full body armor against all creepy predators (she has a tendency for the dramatics). In a few months this area will all be under snow and ice until next spring.

media.title: It's roll call, time to go in and be accounted for, upon entry I go directly to the treat cabinet, this is my reward for following instructions. Don't tell The Warden but I'm not really following instructions I'm just going in for the treat and besides I pretty much sniffed the whole yard so I'm ready to go in. This works out for both of us, The Warden thinks she has complete control (she has control issues) and I get what I want, a treat, it's a win win.

What do you do when you find a blanket in your way, you claim it, this is now officially blanket number four to be added to my lounger. Someone thought with the cooler weather it be a great idea to get one of the forbidden throws out of storage hoping I would have forgotten about my time spent yanking, dragging, barking, biscuit burying, slobber, hair and sweetly scented blanket, yes all this brings back fond memories.

Happy Thanksgiving from our family to yours, we have so much to be thankful for. This is my brother and me just chillin while The Warden is fussing in the kitchen (I'm watching her every move), we are being thankful for turkey, gravy, cheese and spending time together (my brother is thankful for carrot cake).

Take one last look (or sniff) at the foliage, the happy clipper has a gleam in her eye and is preparing to wipe out the entire area. I've been told to clear out (hey hey) as she lays out her tools, she also has a broom as part of her toolkit (who doesn't), her motto is leave no dirt behind, it's also part of her therapy so it has a duel purpose (have I mentioned she has issues).

What do you do when you find a jacket laying on the ground, no other choice but to lay on it. Oh I suppose I could've dragged it around and barked at it, maybe had someone chase after me then had a tug-a-war, all good options but I decided to enjoy the warmth of the sun and watch The Warden work, besides it's exhausting watching someone else working.

There's a hint of movement outside, not enough to ramp it up but at the ready just in case. With the leaves falling and blowing around it can become a distraction, it's almost like shadows, what's bark worthy, you have to be selective or you'd be exhausted from barking all the time. That's why if anyone comes close to the door I'm ready for a full on barking reception, so brace yourself because there's gonna be some jumping, can't be helped I'm expressive and emotional.

Throwback to yesterday when I was helping in the urban jungle, the destruction has begun. We've been getting a fair amount of rain so walking under these plants is the equivalent to getting a shower, therefore under Basset rules this counts as a bath. According to my recent bath schedule I'm not due for a full tub bath until 2020, sometime in the late summer (no baths allowed during the fall or winter season).

I was outside doing what we all do, sniffing, when I suddenly looked up and saw something different in the window. I immediately went into the attack position, head down, left paw up, that's when I raised the alarm and howled, all the time keeping an eye on the intruder in the window. Over my shoulder I could hear this warning 'hey hey', it was The Warden running over to help fight off the offender. Well, it turned out to be a vase of freshly cut flowers, this time, never let your guard down, next time you could be fighting for your life.

I hear this all the time 'settle down', I believe it's the same as 'calm down', which really means someone's tolerance level is at an all time low. The barking and yawning is a symptom of neglect, it happens when The Warden decides to settle in and read. The highly recommended remedy for a severe case of neglect is to offer some medicinal cheese (aged cheese), it offers immediate results.

There's always something curious about a fenced in porch and it must be investigated. It's designed to keep intruders away but it has the opposite effect, makes you wonder what it is that they are protecting. Maybe they don't want company, delivery people or snoopy neighbours, but it certainly makes you wonder what's going on. Not to worry, I'll be back and I'm on the case now trying to see what they're hiding from.

Don't worry about me, take your time, I'll just be waiting here for someone (anyone) to go outside with me. I know you got important things to do, please go ahead, I'll be here all by myself, tucked away, you'll hardly notice me, I'll just stick my nose up to the door if I need some fresh air. I'll get a little exercise when I stretch and rotate, please go on about your business, don't trouble yourself with little ole me.

There's a basic rule when sleeping on the bed, I must sleep on the blue blanket. When I initially get on the bed every hair on my body is on the blanket, now here's where things go off the rails, The Warden gets up, adjusts the bed cover (she has issues) and I instinctively move to the warm spot (can't be blamed for a manoeuvre in a sleep induced state), actually when you break it all down technically I'm not responsible, The Warden is responsible for creating a warm spot which lead me to follow my instincts. This is my prepared opening argument if this goes to trial.

I did a thorough job checking out the front yard, well as far as my line would allow, that was after a rabbit jumped out of the flowers.  I was snoozing on the driveway when I heard this shriek from The Warden, she was trimming the flowers when all of a sudden a rabbit ran out. I unfortunately missed the whole event but went in after to secure the area. This urban living is not for the timid, we've got squirrels climbing trees, chipmunks running amuck and now rabbits jumping out of the flowers.

title: Throwback to when I was inside the gated community (the little ugly fences) and before The Warden got clipper happy and destroyed most of the plants. The patch of dirt where the grass wouldn't grow was eventually replaced with sod, just so you know I had nothing to do with any of this, just the way things go or don't grow. At least with the plants removed I can now stretch out and look out over my kingdom (exercise yard). As a side note the urban jungle remains in tact for another few weeks, The Warden is doing her clipping in stages.

media.title: Being in The Wardens chair can go one of three ways, first she can totally ignore me because she has other things to do (not my preferred choice). Secondly she can go to another room and try to convince me someone is at the door (she's kinda wore out this ruse). Her third and final choice (my favourite) is to immediately turn around, get a piece of cheese, toss it on my lounger,  which will then motivate me to move out of her beloved chair. There's a fourth choice but it involves a third party where I steal their chair, it's a complicated scenario. Today is all about choices, be thankful you have them.

What most people don't see while looking at me in the garden having a reflective moment is the dirt on my paws. Then there are those who have issues and will automatically zero in on the tiniest bit of dirt. Not to worry, the grass is wet so by the time I get across the yard all the dirt will be gone and the only thing you will see is wet paw prints, see there is a rainbow at the end of this story.

Why do I have three blankets on my lounger, it's a frequently asked question. The first blanket was to keep the lounger from getting dirty, it's easier to wash the blanket than it is the lounger. The second blanket appeared when I started to bury my biscuits, theory was I would dig up the top blanket and bury on first blanket. The third blanket was added thinking that an additional layer would be harder to remove therefore preserving the life expectancy of the lounger. All three blankets were tucked in tight using the hospital corners method, well you see how that worked out.

This urban jungle has only a few days left before it becomes a barren wasteland. The Wardens got a gleam in her twitching eye as she chops off each plant while preparing the garden for winter, therefore I'm taking advantage of my jungle retreat. I'm also harvesting my garden memories for the long winter season ahead, it was a good time this year in the garden with no fences and full access. No harm came to any plants over the spring and summer, a little digging never hurt anything, trust should be restored.

I have excellent hearing but it's selective, I'm very motivated when I want to be, also its been pointed out I have a tendency to be stubborn but that's only because I'm very selective. Above all else be yourself, if it takes awhile to get where you're going so be it, life's a journey not a marathon. Sometimes you're surrounded by a lot of noise so if you choose to hear the crinkle of a cheese bag so be it. Celebrate who you are and embrace your uniqueness, Miss Lilly's thoughtful moment of the day.

The sky's are lit up, there's rolling thunder, it's so loud you couldn't even hear The Warden sing if you wanted to (there's been no requests to date). Needless to say I'm not going outside, you'll find me on my lounger blocking out all distractions, unless for course someone moves from their chair then I'll relocate (I've been training for this moment my whole life, it helps when you are held captive by a wannabe entertainer with a restraining order).

title: Throwback to the last few days where I waited and waited for someone to stop by. I'm assigned a couple of hours each day to the front yard under the watchful eye of The Warden, the line that I'm tethered to is a carefully calculated length that allows me to go only to the property edge. I have free reign in the backyard only because it's fenced in and I can't scale the fence, also no one other than The Warden goes back there so I prefer the front.

media.title: When planning a garden it's important to remember to leave enough room between plants for a Basset ornament, it's a conversation piece and adds to the overall beauty. These ornaments have an independent spirit and are prone to wander off and sniff at a moments notice. Do not attempt to engage in any fetch activities but will enthusiastically accept a nicely arranged cheese platter with a bowl of fresh filtered water with ice.

Patience is a virtue, said no one. I was made to wait because I asked to go outside as a ploy to get a treat, maybe or once I got outside I could've changed my mind, it happens. It's not like the staff were busy or in the middle of a shimmy (not shimmy music), it's all about control, once again applying heavy tactics to get me to conform to some household rule. I was rewarded a treat not because I didn't follow the rules but because I was a good girl.

Say it isn't so, no don't tell me, it can't be Monday already, I'm just a few naps short of a really great weekend. Therefore my plan today is to catch up on a few naps, steal as many chairs as possible, be on a high cheese alert, go for a sniff (aka walk), soak up a little sun, bark for much needed attention, do a little biscuit dance, kick up a little dust and see if I can't get The Wardens eye twitching. High expectations but all manageable.

Ever wonder what goes on in the deep dark recesses of the urban jungle, not much, a few weeds, couple of chipmunk trails, the odd tuff of rabbit fur, no hidden treasure or the usual big game animal except for me. The only hazards that I've encountered so far are wet leaves and spy cameras, other than that all is secure in the backyard urban jungle.  This has been an updated report from your local resident Miss Lilly.

Someone, anyone, I'm here waiting, if you're looking for a little attention or want to be fussed over please stop by. I'll be here sitting on the new grass, just ignore the lady behind me, she's always telling me to get off the grass (I've already christened the grass numerous times). There's one workman that comes over everyday, he gives me lots of rubs and calls me 'his girl', it's well worth the wait. You also hear this little voice in the background 'no jumping no jumping', sounds like a broken record.

title: Tap tap tap.....tap tap tap, then the house became eerily quiet, The Warden was on high alert trying to locate the tapping noise, then suddenly she looks to the fireplace and sees a mouse trying to push a biscuit through the grate (I've tried this once before it doesn't fit). As you can imagine this set off a flurry of activity, the crisis management team was called in (dad) to defuse the situation. The biscuit was recovered, the mouse disappeared, we are not moving to a high rise, The Warden is doing much better thank you, but if you want to contribute to her well being a cheese basket would be greatly appreciated.

Throwback to the day The Warden discovered I had hoarding tendencies, she was wrong, she just bought the wrong kind of biscuits, they weren't gravy coated. I buried all these biscuits in the couch and chair, only to be discovered when the furniture got lumpy. After this event The Warden developed extreme issues, she now regularly pats down the furniture and watches me like a hawk (still looking online for a biscuit detector).

media.title: I might've got in a wee bit of trouble for barking in the closet (again), the door was left open (like an invitation) so I decided to go in and check things out. What's the big deal about barking in a closet, the acoustics are great but still The Warden gets all in a flap and says nobody wants to hear that noise. She even raised her voice, yelled a couple of hey heys, pointed her finger and told me to get out, she appears to be a bit touchy today (well it's every time I bark in the closet which she says has become a habit).

Just another quiet moment, me and my gravy coated biscuit and the surveillance camera. It's interesting that someone with issues spends every waking moment up in my business, but if I were to watch her eating a snack that's a different story, she almost has to go into hiding to avoid anyone from watching her eat (each and every bite). I personally don't have issues watching someone eat just as long as they share, if you withhold there will be some whining whimpering drooling nudging until you hand over the goods (why wouldn't you want to share).

I've done my work for the day and the day hasn't even officially started (starts after brunch). It's not easy keeping up with The Warden, she tucks my blankets in around the lounger which I then have to do a yank drag and bark routine (formally known as the Biscuit Dance, with or without the biscuit). Well I nap The Warden will restore order, she'll try her hospital corners tucking of the blankets again (because it works so well), at least this gives her a sense of purpose.

title: Smile she says, come on work the camera, say cheese, now we're talking, she had me at cheese. I personally think someone has too much time on their hands, isn't there something that needs to be cleaned, maybe a few weeds picked out of the grass, oh look, there's some dirt on the driveway, that'll entertain her for a few minutes and I can go back to some important napping.

All the blankets on my lounger were just freshly washed, The Warden meticulously tucked in all the blankets trying to maintain a sense of order (she has issues). Well we'll see about that, first you grab on the blanket and start yanking, not to worry if the lounger moves just keep yanking. This was the best yank ever, all three blankets came off in one try, couldn't ask for a better result (The Warden doesn't try to interfere mid yank because then it turns into a different scenario, tug-of-war).

media.title: Nature called so I decided to get up early this morning, it was still dark outside so I took care of business and then decided to explore. I could hear a slight commotion on the deck, my name being shouted out by The Warden and her accomplice (dad), all of which I ignored, next there were two spotlights pointed at me like I was an escaped convict. This just shows you their insecurities, I'm out of sight for a few minutes and then all hell breaks loose, lights beaming over the yard, frantic calls, all this because of a meandering sniff, talk about issues.

Throwback to one of my finer moments when I actually stole The Wardens chair with her book on the seat, usually this is a deterrent but I took a chance (in order to properly reserve a chair the book must be placed in the middle). It paid off, I nestled onto the book (a little lumpy but manageable), got the predictable eye twitch and 30 seconds later in she stomps with a piece of cheese (perfectly tossed onto my lounger). It was a win win, she got her chair back and I got my cheese.

It's Ask Miss Lilly time, ever wondered about something, I have the answer. I often get asked why Shimmy Shaking Momma has a restraining order (for life), she once free styled in public, authorities were called, she tried to shimmy her way out of an arrest, lawyers were involved and pled down to the restraining order. The end result was no public display of any form of body movements resembling a shimmy, it's deemed a public service. Have a burning question, just ask Miss Lilly.

It's gonna be quiet on the street today, all the kids are back to school, I'll have to depend on random delivery trucks to bark at. I could always bark at The Warden but she's predictable, she'll threaten to take me inside, she'll say nobody wants to hear that noise, throw in a couple of 'hey hey's', it's the same thing every time. Why not try something different, unhook this chain, let me wander around the neighbourhood, nobody's home they won't even notice, come on just once try something different.

Sometimes I think I should sell tickets to those that want to watch me sleep, I can hear the tiptoeing into the room, feel the long lingering gaze, the whispering 'she's a good girl', yes yes I'm a good girl, so either back on out and let me sleep or you be a good girl and whip up a little something in the kitchen.

Sometimes it's a struggle to get the right conditions in order to eat your gravy coated biscuit. It's all in the preparation, first yank out those tucked in hospital corners (please note there are three blankets, extra work), drag and bark until you get the appropriate amount of attention, casually glance up to ensure they are enjoying the performance, when you've exhausted all efforts then return to your lounger and enjoy your biscuit (the staff will tidy up after, not to worry).

The Warden was once again trying to play fetch, she was thinking I'd participate but I thought she was doing alright running back and forth by herself. When you think about it what's the point in playing fetch, you throw the ball, expect someone else to retrieve it, then you end up getting the ball yourself only to repeat the same thing over again. Now if you'd try throwing cheese I'd be doing sprints and backflips, now that's a game that would take no coaxing.

Making a perfect nest in the sun took a little work, first I had to yank all the blankets off my lounger, drag them across the floor and behind the chair, while barking the whole time, then finally after an exhausting yank, drag and bark I could settle in for a sunny nap. I'm not sure everyone appreciated all my efforts, there was some 'hey hey's' and a few 'settle downs', nothing I haven't heard before, so I just ignored it all.

Throwback to the days when I could just innocently look into your eyes and without begging you would slip me a treat. Those were the days, now we have this so called healthy lifestyle choices, the constant scrutiny of ones girth, the itsy bitsy teeny weeny portions (one level above a sniff), all of this depriving only enhances ones begging tendencies (it's an art form).

title: There were six workmen across the street, two were working, the rest were chatting and not one came over to visit with me. Of course they knew I was there because The Warden kept telling me to be quiet. Would it be too much trouble to set up a BBQ and offer the workmen some lunch, isn't that what neighbours should do, The Warden needs to work on neighbour relations.

media.title: I managed to steal The Wardens chair, it's a special moment, I even brought a snack because I'm here for the long haul. As she rounds the corner and first sees me, there's a little huff, the shoulders drop, the inevitable eye twitch, she's assessed the situation and realizes there's only one way to resolve this. Yes, she took a deep breath, backed up, opened the fridge, got a slice of cheese and tossed it on my lounger, works every time.

There was an incident yesterday, someone brought a bunch of balloons into the house, which is a sign of evil and I had no other choice but to set the howling alarm off. It was a howl like none other, I was in the attack position, front paws aggressively pawing at the floor, my head dipping low then upwards into the howl, until eventually the evil balloons were removed. I'm recommending a sign be posted at the door, No Balloons Allowed Ever.

It's National Dog Day and in order to properly celebrate the occasion I give you the Biscuit Dance. First yank the blankets off your bed, drop a moist gravy coated biscuit on the blanket, do a little two step clicking motion, then commence with the barking and dragging. This performance usually draws an audience, try to maintain your focus, don't make eye contact as the crowd chants for more (at least that's what I hear).

What do you do when you have full access to the garden, well you seize the moment and bury a gravy coated biscuit. Once the little ugly fences came down the doors of opportunity opened up, the only obstacle is getting past The Warden with your biscuit. A key point here is to tuck the biscuit under your lip, do not make eye contact and go to the door with a sense of urgency.

Every once in awhile you get lucky and sneak one by The Warden, she has rules about eating gravy coated biscuits on the bed. If you tuck the biscuit under your lip just before she lifts you up on the bed, bingo, what's she gonna do now, except take responsibility for breaking her own rule, it's called aiding and abetting.

Throwback to yesterday, I was standing by the treat cabinet when I happened to notice some movement outside, I took a huntress stance, The Warden quietly opened the door, I sprang into action and almost leaped off the deck, the rabbit started darting all over the yard, I momentarily lost sight of it as I stopped to pick up a scent. All of a sudden I heard this shriek, I turned around and saw The Warden pointing at the rabbit, I took chase again and the frightened rabbit slithered under the gate. The Warden has fully recovered, I got my treat and then spent some time recovering from my hunting adventure.

There was a storm coming so we set up camp in the garage, got my blanket, fresh filtered water with ice, and The Wardens chair (within easy access to scratches). I can still watch all the action on the street and I noticed that the workmen across the street left early without a drop of rain falling yet, I'll be verifying their time card with the nosey neighbours tally (of course I don't see when they start because I'm still sleeping).

Could you say that again, I must've misunderstood you the first time, did you say no more treats or ten more treats because clearly I'm going with ten more treats. I'm not making this stuff up, I heard what I heard, there's no going from zero to ten, no backing up on a verbal agreement. Ok ok, you appear a little rattled, let's settle on eight more treats, as you can see I'm willing to negotiate which allows you to maintain your control issues and your dignity.

All household activities have been suspended until further notice, I'll make another announcement as soon as I'm able to. Please don't let this announcement deter you from whipping up a little something in the kitchen if you so feel inspired, even if you're not inspired your efforts would be greatly appreciated. Without providing too much of a hint, nothing gets the blood flowing like the smell of bacon wafting through the air.

title: One of the main attractions to these flowers are the butterflies, which apparently are to be left in peace. Now there's clearly a temptation to chase a butterfly, which would mean entering into the forbidden garden, but if you think about it, I'm like a butterfly, a slip of a girl floating in the air like a gentle breeze, you'd hardly know I was even there (not to worry most flowers are able to bounce back once trampled upon).

media.title: Every day I'm allowed an escorted visit to the front yard under the watchful eye of The Warden, this allows me an opportunity to see what goes on in the outside world. Of course there are restrictions, must be tethered, no barking, no jumping on visitors, no digging or laying on the flowers, no snacks but I do get fresh filtered water with ice (legal requirement during hot weather). Even though there are limitations it is my favourite time of the day.

Sometimes a little whining is essential when you're feeling neglected, not a lot, just enough to get the required attention. Of course along with the attention comes the standard 'hey hey', eye twitches, hand clapping, all of this is a total waste of time, save your energy and give me lots of scratches, rubs and all that sweet talk about cheese.

Throwback to when I once again had to overcome another obstacle, the little ugly fences. Please note that I did not roll on the fresh dirt, it was a little cramped to do a full leg thrust roll, couldn't risk getting trapped and tangled up in the fence (I know my limitations).

Well checking out the neighbours yard I thought I saw a chipmunk darting in the bushes, probably shaking with fear after seeing me or laughing at The Warden who jumps in fear at the sight of a critter. These are not nightmare varmints to be feared, even though they have been known to mock and chatter after a round of hissing from The Warden (they'd probably run in fear if she sang or danced but with the restraining order she is prohibited from doing either).

title: One minute I'm wrapped up in The Wardens throw, after a battle of yanking and dragging, the next minute the throw mysteriously disappears. Home should be where there's hair in the air, slobber, drool and smelly blankets, it's an atmosphere where guests want to kick off their shoes and relax. Guests don't want someone to pluck hair off their clothing or to be offered a wet wipe for some misplaced slobber, offer snacks and all else will be forgiven.

media.title: My mornings are all about recuperating from a long night of sleeping, can't just rush into the day. I'll eventually get up to stretch and rotate, I also have my radar tuned into The Warden, I know every move she's making, laundry, vacuuming, dusting, fussing, when it gets quiet that's when I become fully alert, she could be sneaking snacks (she has a shady history with snack issues and I have remarkable timing).

Beautiful summer day, the conditions are almost perfect, there's my bowl of fresh filtered water with ice, my blanket covered with hair and slobber that's laid out beside The Wardens chair (easy access for rubs), the only thorn in this whole scenario is being tethered to a tree. Humiliating comes to mind, I'm restricted to a small area, not allowed to bark freely and under the watchful eye of someone who has control issues (not to mention her restraining order).

The Warden got a bit snippy on my walk, accused me of putting on the brakes excessively and attempting to sniff every blade of grass, all true but I have an excuse what's hers. The sidewalks, every corner, fresh dirt, grass, plants, bushes, the air is exploding with scents, so take a deep breath, relax and enjoy the journey.

Guess what I discovered in the backyard, the little ugly fences, they're hoping to keep me out and off the new dirt (who can resist fresh smelling dirt). Well we'll see about that, where there's a will there's a way. Fresh dirt is meant to be rolled on, I'm just flat out saying it, this may take some time but I'll figure it out, let's see now, the construction is a little flimsy but points for effort.

title: Throwback to yesterday when I supervised the rebuilding of the front lawn, it had crabs (crabgrass). I was asked to supervise from the sidelines when the grass seed was distributed and The Warden insisted on putting up the little ugly fences.  I've been banned from one of life's true pleasures, oh what rolling good times will be missed and maybe just maybe a little bit of digging.

media.title: Watching the kids on our street play road hockey, they must be good because not one ball came my way. Even though I was napping I was ready to spring into action, if the coach said Miss Lilly we need you, I'm there, put me in coach, I'll play defense, forward, goalie or just hand out snacks, just say the word, please call me.

Biscuit burying is an art, it varies in individual style, I personally like to include the interactive barking. Once the barking starts an audience shows up, it adds tension and drama, there's the ever popular eye twitch, the crowd yelling 'hey hey' (I hear 'more more'). The duration of each performance varies, sometimes it depends on the tolerance level or my energy level, whatever breaks first.

I'm at the recharge station, should be fully activated by brunch or the crinkle of a cheese wrapper, whatever comes first. I just finished a heavy round of extreme fitness, full body workout, yanking (upper body), tugging (abs), barking (vocal cords) and blanket dragging (core). I've trained for this event, years of experience, the key to my success is in the recovery, let your body completely rest between each event.

There we go, with just a little extra effort those hospital corners slip right off, if at first you don't succeed try try again (ancient Basset saying). Burying a biscuit is not as easy as one may think, it involves a lot of necessary barking, some yanking and tugging, doing all this while you know who is giving you 'the look', of course this only encourages me, my own personal cheering section.

Sometimes you have to make a sacrifice while enjoying the sun. What's missing is a lounger, the ice has melted in my water, no accessible fridge (one of my pet peeves indoors or outdoors), no one in sight to bark at, the only creature stirring is The Warden who is constantly hovering over me.

Good thing I'm patrolling the exercise yard, looks like a varmint has created a nest under the plants. This plant was damaged from the winter weather and is in a delicate state, what it doesn't need is some creature digging and stomping around it, thank goodness I discovered this before any further damage was done. Please note that no damage was done during this inspection, I'm a trained professional, I've learned to tread ever so lightly, like a gentle breeze.

Throwback to the days when the roast simmered all day and the gravy flowed freely, these were the good ole days before gravy became seasonal. Nowadays we are at the mercy of someone who has lifestyle issues, also cheese should not be considered an occasional snack, it's a nutritional requirement which should be served at every meal, also before and after each nap.

You are all invited to do a jungle tour, for those of you that are brave enough to enter the unknown. It's dark, spin tingling, dangerous, lurking critters and a few weeds. You are in a confined space, plants crawling all over you, definitely not enough room to shimmy (someone was inquiring), enter at your own risk if you dare.

One of the greatest pleasures is stealing a chair, consider this a hostage situation, let the negotiations begin. Of course there's that awkward moment of the predictable eye twitch, the sighing (moaning and groaning) and the shuffling around. All this precious time wasted debating what to do, save us all the dramatics, this will go one of two ways, first I'll settle in and you'll lose your spot or, wait for it, you'll get me some cheese and you get your chair back, it's as simple as that, it's not rocket science.

All quiet on the home front, this is what life has become, as soon as I have a spirited bark at anyone (or anything) there's the threat of 'we are going inside if you bark'. It's not like I'm barking for hours, it's just a little peep, hardly notice I'm around but there's always that one person that gets all tied up in knots, you know the party pooper. Now might be the time to bring up when shimmy shaking momma burst out in song and the neighbour yelled 'knock it off lady', this was of course before the restraining order.

Did you realize that when in a sitting position there's the impression you appear heavier, it's an illusion. Now if I stood up what you see is a slip of a girl, ribs jutting out, one meal away from fainting, someone who makes you want to rush to the fridge for an emergency piece of cheese (for strength because you care). Images are powerful, don't judge at first glance, but be warned, if you have a basset running to greet you then prepare to brace yourself, even the teeny tiny can knock you down.

I've been doing some thinking, The Warden says I'm not treat motivated therefore I'm difficult to train, which I interrupt as she has control issues. I'm a free spirit and I know what I want when I want it, what's the problem. Does she really want me to sit on demand, shake a paw, roll over, fetch a ball, really, think about it, that's just not me. Ask yourself this, is this really about me or the one with the control issues, these pondering moments brought to you by Miss Lilly.

Things were going along great, I slept a good 12-14 hours, went for my morning walk (sniff), barked at the neighbours, then all of a sudden dad and I are getting in the truck. Window down, ears flopping in the breeze, people pointing at me, all was good until, until we stopped at the torture clinic. They were savages getting pleasure out of cutting off my nails, these places need to be banned from society and to top it off no complimentary snacks.

Throwback to when my brother was last home and we were chatting it up about the upcoming hockey season. There's excitement in the air (The Warden said hair in the air) also hoping to get tickets to a game, especially if (when) the Leafs make the playoffs (you just gotta believe). The Warden was looking at us with that twitchy eye and visions of running the vacuum over me (won't happen but let her dream).

There's a rule in our house (go figure) when you're on the bed you have to lay on a special blanket, you're not to lay directly on the bed cover. So well nesting and preparing my spot I inadvertently tossed the blanket aside and now only a small portion of my butt is touching the blanket, according to Basset rules this qualifies as a safety zone, therefore overriding the original house rule, it's a complicated system but rules are rules.

I think I've been exposed to The Wardens issues too much, I'm starting to develop tendencies of being neat and tidy. I haven't quite mastered the technique of hospital corners but then again my issues aren't teetering on the edge and I'm not burdened with restraining orders.

Monday Motivational Pep Talk, put your paws in the air like you just don't care, what are they gonna do, drag you to work. I have a schedule, it just doesn't start till later, in the meantime I'm contemplating my next strategic move, maybe I'll do a half roll and a stretch, naw too much like exercise, gotta slow it down a tad, I'm in the slow lane so just ease on around me.

Don't be so quick to judge, stirring up a little dirt in the garden is not a bad thing, unless of course you're someone who has a lot of issues. The vines I stepped on (like a gentle breeze) are violators from the neighbours garden so it doesn't count, the sprinkling of dirt on the rocks (I bet you didn't notice) will be cleaned up in no time, the person with issues carries a little brush at all times for such emergencies (imagined or real, try not to judge).

I know what you're thinking so stop right there, I'm just admiring the garden. I bet you thought I was scouting out a burial site for my biscuits, since the bushes have all been trimmed there appears to be a little more room for walking (digging) around, what a shame not to take advantage of this opportunity, but no, and it's not because there's eyes in the sky if you know what I mean (yes it's because I'm being watched).

There are a few times a day where The Wardens hackles rise to the occasion, she has a low tolerance for barking but if I can also be entertaining I get a few extra minutes before she shuts it all down. Just before she has a meltdown she starts off by saying 'hey hey' (classic manoeuvre), moves on the clapping her hands, may stand and change the tone of her command, the last and final distraction would be to leave and open the fridge door, bingo, works every time.

Throwback to the good ole days when I used to go in the wine cellar (closet) and yank The Wardens housecoat off the hangar and drag it all over. Yes there was a lot of barking, but come on, who doesn't bark when you're doing a yank and drag. This area is now considered forbidden and sealed off (door closed), there was that time where I had one forceful yank and a section of the shelf fell apart, an antique iron fell on the floor and the calvary came running, yes, the good ole days.

Dad had friends over for cards last night, there were lots of snacks and sandwiches and all I got was a list of rules. No jumping up on guests when they arrive (only jumped on about half), no begging for food (had to because none was offered) and finally no barking (who doesn't bark at a party). It was a long evening and I partied until the last guest left, today will be a recovery day, all day long.

Why do some get to have bacon while others don't, is this a sign of neglect, incompetence or just laziness. It surely can't be a lifestyle choice because who would ever in their right mind not choose bacon, oh yeah, someone with issues. Please send help to a worthy cause #freethebacon, we are also accepting any donations to help support those that are not as fortunate as others.

Chip in and lend a helping paw when you can, it may not be perfect, may not have hospital corners but it's about making an effort and lightening the load for others. No need to ever wash my blankets, take that chore off your list, no need for a bath ever, another one crossed off, I'm here to smooth the way to a better day. Motivational moments to start your week by Miss Lilly.

Apparently there's a rule about expressing oneself when outside, in my own yard I might add and in the middle of the afternoon. The Warden doesn't think others fully appreciate my call for attention, so as soon as I bark she gets all in a flap and try's to dampen my spirit, in the end I get extra attention so the lesson learned is barking works. It's not about rewarding bad behaviour it's about giving attention to those that need it.

Relax, nothing to see here, move along, no need to fuss. The Warden had all the bushes trimmed so there was a little extra room to bury a biscuit. Not to worry about the dirt on the driveway, the staff carry's a broom in their arsenal of yard tools and not a speck of dirt was seen after.  What you don't see is the little ugly fence between the bushes, so there's no short cuts to the front yard and I don't need emergency services to untangle my line.

Due to the heightened security threats around our front gardens I decided to bury my treat in the neighbours garden. My friend the delivery guy dropped off another treat for me and because he was working he couldn't hang around to see what I do with the treats. Please don't tell the neighbours about the buried treat, if they ask all you saw was a helping paw doing a little weeding, it's the kind of thing neighbours do to help out.

Throwback to a sneak peek at the garden when a decision was made to not install the little ugly fences this year. Wise decision, the plants need to be free and not caged in, they were meant to mingle with the environment and what it has to offer, to overcome all obstacles, live and let live and all that other stuff. I was also meant to mingle, occasionally bury a biscuit and to feel the soft plants under my paws as I tip toe through the garden.

Looking for your next roll is best done without prying eyes, you need less distractions so your nose can zero in on that one delightful scent. What you don't need is someone saying 'hey hey' just as you're leaning in to get a little dab on the neck. Without the yank just get right in there, start with your neck, slide onto your back, legs in the air and wiggle around, pure magic. Not every roll ends in a bath so don't let that stop you, enjoy the moment and let's hope that one day you won't be judged on what you smell like.

How many yawns does it take before you're fully awake?  There's no right or wrong answer, most times after a series of yawns I fall back to sleep and have to start all of again, it's a process. Might I suggest if you want a full body wagging tail, dancing around, bright eyes and fully alert, just bring on the cheese, nothing says good morning like cheese.

Sometimes you have to work a little harder for what you want but the end result is worth all that extra effort. Yes I had to untuck the blanket (hospital corners), bury my biscuit, find the biscuit and then savour the moment. And who says bassets aren't in shape, burying a biscuit requires you to be in top physical condition, you can't do what I just did without intense training and lots of naps (recovery phase). I'm a fitness fanatic taking it to a whole new level, doing it basset style.

title: Bring all the pillows and blankets you want outside but sometimes a rock under a bush is just as comfy. I was also curled up in such a way that it distorted my rippling abs, this is what happens when the muscles all bunch up together. The Warden also discovered a biscuit under a bush, big adventurous day in the garden.

media.title: Guilty as charged, I didn't once hesitate or consider another option, I crossed the line and have no regrets. The delivery guy stopped and gave me a special treat so I circled around with it for a minute then decided to bury it and what better place then in amongst the flowers. Damages were minimal, The Warden might have to tidy up a bit and clip a couple of bent limbs, she said I was like a bull in a china shop, not funny, I was a faint delicate breeze whispering through the flowers.

Miracles do come true, I was outside lounging on the grass when out of nowhere this knight in shining armour showed up bearing gifts. I was presented with a bowl of hamburger, outdoor dining at it's finest, surrounded by nature's beauty. Fortunately there was no resistance from The Warden who is firm on protocol, she has issues with eating outside.

Throwback to yesterday when all was quiet in the neighbourhood until the squealing started, a baby bird took flight for the first time and landed on The Wardens shoulder, that's when all the flapping started and it wasn't from the baby bird.  I jumped into action once I saw the attack, the bird immediately took flight and all seemed quiet except for the heavy breathing, that's about the time a second baby bird fell from the tree and bounced off The Wardens back then took flight. No medics or emergency services were required during this incident, just a few deep breathing exercises calmed her down.

I thought I heard someone say cheese or maybe I was hoping for a miracle and I'd wake up to find a platter of a cheese nicely displayed. As I've heard many times if you're gonna dream, dream big, because sometimes dreams do come true. I have visions of a large roast simmering in gravy, my gravy dippers are tingling with anticipation, oh the good life.

Dog days of summer, it's about laying under the shade of the tree while the gentle breeze fluffs your hair. It's about waiting for the staff to refresh your ice water and straighten your blanket, it's the small things that make for a perfect summer day. Everything moves slower during the hot weather, even the tassels on The Wardens pedal pushers have lost their usual bounce.

When you're dealing with extreme weather it's best to conserve energy, no sudden movements unless of course you see someone, then you're required to ramp it up. Limit your full exposure to the direct sun, of course I have someone watching over me at all times, my ice water is refreshed numerous times, my hairy blanket spread out and upon request some scratches and rubs (nudging may be required), overall the service has been great.

title: Happy Canada Day, we are proud to be Canadian ð¨ð¦. I'm very fortunate in many ways, we celebrate our freedom (as far as the leash allows), we have plenty to eat (still working on seasonal turkey), we have a welcoming community (squirrels, rabbits, chipmunks and the occasional cat), we have tolerance and acceptance (The Warden) and most of all we are surrounded and loved by family and friends.

media.title: Take a walk on the wild side, get out of your comfort zone, do something crazy, that's exactly what I did when I did the jungle tour. The sights and sounds, the occasional drops of water and of course the element of danger will only heighten your experience. This is not for the timid or for those that have issues, once you mix a little water with dirt you're looking at a possibility of mud, very dangerous stuff.

Add this to my list of proud moments, I slipped past security and buried a biscuit in the forbidden front yard garden. The biscuit was neatly tucked under my lip and even The Warden couldn't detect it as she put my shackles on for my scheduled release in the front yard. She's currently on the internet looking for a device that will detect contraband (biscuits) before leaving the facility (house), did I happen to mention that she has issues.

Throwback to some winter fun and to remind us of the colder weather because we are coming into a heat wave, record setting. I'm hoping that The Warden is prepared, a cooling mat on the driveway for when I sunbathe, extra ice for my water and air conditioning under the front yard tree. It's the small things that give us the greatest pleasures and if you're in the giving mood a small roast simmering in gravy under the tree would be lovely.

title: I left The Warden in charge of securing the area while I was having a moment of reflection, during that time a squirrel ran past us and went up the tree and a chipmunk was only inches from her foot. Yes there was squealing, pointing, a big fuss was being made while I maintained my composure and dignity, I also checked to see if the neighbours were alerted, it wouldn't look good at her parole hearing if the authorities were called.

media.title: Whenever there's a little ruckus The Warden comes running trying to control the situation, this was the post biscuit dance, the major event is now over so best move along. At times like this just ignore and try not to make eye contact, she'll eventually saunter off hopefully to the kitchen, that's where she is truly appreciated and she has full control. If you want to build your self esteem try throwing a turkey in the oven.

We've fought a good battle and won, now gravy can be served year round, it is not seasonal. The Warden seems to be selective about what is considered seasonal, isn't flannel on the seasonal list or one would think so, but no, apparently it's comfort wear. My next mission is to move turkey off the endangered seasonal list and make it a year round meal with all the trimmings. #freetheturkey

My brother is home and admiring my gravy dippers, doesn't matter if they're a little crusty it's about sharing time together. Even though it's not officially gravy season The Warden surprised us all with roast simmering in gravy and my dippers did a little swimming. The Warden was shamed and outed for saying gravy was seasonal, the protesters outside our house can now go home knowing you have righted a wrong. Thank you for your commitment to gravy.

What could be more important than a scratching session with your brother, after this there should be a good inch of hair on the floor. How do I know this was time well spent, it would be The Eye Twitching Warden hovering in the background, most moms would be fondly looking on creating beautiful memories not having visions of getting the vacuum out, did I happen to mention she has issues.

They've crossed the line, against my will I was thrown in the tub and given a bath with lavender soap, imagine smelling like that, it was dreadful. I'm hopeful that I can find something to roll on and for the record I didn't stink and I certainly didn't deserve this kind of abuse. My next scheduled bath was suppose to be in the spring of 2020, this is clearly a violation and all those who participated should be arrested.

Throwback to the time I had to wait at the door to go out, I didn't really need to go out I just wanted a treat. I somehow think they're on to me because the service is getting a little slow. Why can't I get my treat first, for strength, then I'll go outside, maybe, and not just any treat it has to be the good stuff.

Taking care of business and doing things my way, the right way. If you're out and about doing a casual stroll and sniff take time to embrace (roll on) what nature has to offer. Also if you're wondering whether or not I've entered the forbidden zone amongst the flowers, well no, not ever, not me, The Warden is doing double duty on securing the flowers. Her lack of trust has reached a whole new level, such beauty should be admired and shared or tasted and rolled on (just kidding, lighten up).

Out of the deep dark recesses of the backyard jungle emerges the fierce hunter known as Miss Lilly, as seen here stalking the local critters who all scurry in fear. My mission is to locate the chipmunk tunnels then The Warden shows up to dismantle and repair the offending areas, all this to be repeated in a few days. Meanwhile up in the trees the squirrels and chipmunks are closely watching, chatting and having a few laughs as critters do, waiting for the inevitable hissing sounds emerging from The Warden.

Some may say I have generous skin flaps around my neck or at this particular angle they appear to be extra fluffy. The real truth is I'm shackled with this collar and chain (line) like a common criminal. I'm given a few hours each day, under surveillance, to enjoy the front yard and experience what life is like for others who are allowed to wander around free without restrictions, oh the good life.

Today is Father's Day so I have the whole day planned out, after my nap of course. Dad and I can lay on the couch together and watch golf, munching on snacks while we wait for The Warden to surprise us with a grand feast. In order to help with his golf game it's important to have strong wrists so I'm offering up myself for unlimited scratches. No need to worry about hair in the air or untucked corners today, just unwind and relax, it's Dads Day.

Thank you for all the Birthday Wishes yesterday, I'm happy to report I received one hamburger cut up into teeny tiny pieces, as per The Wardens instructions. As you can clearly see my gravy dippers are not shiny but are clean, because sadly this is not Gravy Season. I'm requesting that I have another birthday during Gravy Season or we start to allow gravy to be served year round, gravy is comfort food and should not be considered seasonal.

Happy Birthday to Miss Lilly, today she is 6 years old. It'll be a special day, full access to the garden, unlimited chair stealing, definitely some aged cheese, fresh filtered water with ice, ear rubs with scratches and our undivided attention. This may seem like every other day but I assure you it'll be special, if only we can give back a portion of the love we have received over the past six years, thank you Miss Lilly.

Throwback to when I was plotting my next takeover, seat stealing is the ultimate high, so as a public service announcement, don't do drugs, steal seats instead. Once you've stolen your first seat you'll never look back, the warm cozy feeling, you might be given the look and some eye twitching but that's alright, not your problem, just snuggle in a savour the moment.

You do realize that a walk through wet plants count as a bath, what I recommend you do first is roll on a worm before your walk through the plants. I say worm because the pickings are slim around here, if you find a more delightful scent then please substitute. You may also want to chart your baths, if you can accumulate a bunch of wet plant baths this could free you up from having a tub bath all winter, worth a try.

The Warden is trying out a new aerial surveillance technique, it's just as annoying as her regular tactics. The most frightening technique, verging on crazy, would be the night vision goggles and I'm not sure she's even looking for me, a warning should be issued to lower your blinds. The one positive thing about all this surveillance is I know where she is at all times, in case I'm called to be a witness at her trial.

So you say we will have a fun filled day, lots of adventure, a stroll through the neighbourhood, catching a few rays and you do mean later of course, let's say around brunch. Why is it some people feel it's necessary to be so chatty and chipper in the morning, there's no award for this, let's make a deal, I'll come to you when I'm at my full capacity to listen to your heightened enthusiasm, it's a deal right.

My brother held my paw while we watched the Triple Crown horse race, yes it was exciting, I just like to contain myself. Not to overshadow this great event I've also won two Triple Crowns, the first was three biscuit burials, one after another with lightening speed, the second crowning moment was the napathon, three blissful naps in a row. My family is proud of my successes, it's a wonderful thing to have such a supportive family.

When entering in a densely populated area be sure to make your presence known, the last thing you want is for something to sneak up on you. I've noticed a few chipmunk tunnels, a neighbouring plant has snuck under the fence, a couple of tiny weeds but overall the garden is doing well and looks a lot better without those little ugly fences.

All quiet on the home front, not a creature was stirring not even a neighbour nor a workman, delivery guy, mail lady, visitors, nobody in sight, unless you count The Warden and her surveillance equipment. I couldn't even find a worm to roll in but wait a minute, maybe just maybe, if everything lines up, there's a small bird dropping, all is not lost.

It's being reported by an unnamed source with credibility issues that I woke her up in the middle of the night by howling. I'm denying all accusations, I slept like a baby, of course I did my stretching and rotating, one attempt at stealing a warm spot but I did not hear any howling. Maybe this unnamed person with restraining orders against her woke up singing and was confused, just saying.

I'm in the sad section of the garden, very little colour, no flowers and heavily scented with wildlife. The squirrels and chipmunks do battle in the trees above and toss debris all over garden, The Warden has seen the evidence left behind and I have been cleared of all charges. I wouldn't think of leaving a mess like they do, I'd bury it, cover my tracks.

Timing is everything, dad just got up to get a coffee and I was at the right place at the right time, a warm seat. Opportunity presented itself and I sprung into action, not to worry about dad, there are other chairs and he's adaptable. Now if this was The Warden and her chair, different story, she's not adaptable and I'd be licking my lips at a piece of cheese, it's a negotiating tool used to get me to move, works every time.

I was thinking about getting up after a little freshening up (aka bath) but then again maybe not, I'm mulling it over. My morning routine is exhausting, first there's all that stretching, yawning, bathing, more stretching, yawning, this is strenuous exercise, I'm feeling the burn. Great way to start the week with a little cardio before I even hit the floor.

Nothing better than a bowl of fresh filtered water with ice to start your day off, unless of course it's a bowl of gravy but that's another story. The Warden refreshes my water several times a day, she has this thing about everything being fresh, maybe that's how I developed a taste for the finer things life has to offer. As some might have suggested, I do not slurp, I take gentle laps of water to quench my thirst, I would also like a little space as I savour this moment.

Thank goodness I now have access to the garden, there are chipmunk tunnels along the fence, I'm gonna need to double up on the security checks. Not to worry about what looked like a little digging or the brushing up against the plants, I'm like a gentle breeze whisking through the garden. While on patrol you have to let the critters know whose in charge and you mean business, message sent, message received.

title: Saying goodbye to a family of ducks that nested in the neighbours garden, I wasn't allowed to the farewell ceremony, they wanted a quiet send off. I also would've had to get up early, no barking, no chasing, someone would be holding me back yanking on my leash, I didn't get to see the neighbours in their pjs, oh well, at least I got my required amount of sleep.

media.title: Throwback to a few days ago when I was helping in the garden, as you may have noticed there are no little ugly fences, just me and nature mingling together. No fences this year as long as no harm is done to these full gown, sturdy, strong and never give up plants. The Warden figures if the chipmunks and squirrels have access then maybe I should also be allowed, not to worry, the plants and I will get along just fine.

title: The Warden did a safari tour in my exercise yard and was having trouble identifying the local wildlife, it's narrowed down to baby squirrels or chipmunks. On top of having to listen to all the chatter in the trees,  The Warden started hissing, this is how she communicates with nature, warning them to stay out of the garden. When she does this it just gets them all riled up and they chatter back, all I have to do is show up and they scatter.

media.title: Helping out in the garden, The Warden is using garden tools but I like to get in there and give it the personal touch. Aerating the soil is essential, I also think it's important to feed the plants to stimulate growth. Gardening tip:  if you're using the up close and personal touch don't fuss over getting a little dirt on yourself, just do a few rolls on the grass and it'll come right off, maybe you'll get lucky and find a worm to roll on.

These long days of napping in the sun/shade are exhausting, after a few hours I gotta go inside for a cool nap to recover from my outdoor naps. When I first go outside I'm laying flat out on the driveway soaking up the sun, then I'll stretch out in the shade and before you know it I'm laying out in the sun again. When you think about it I'm doing a lot of movement which in my world means I'm exercising, no wonder it's exhausting.

Hard to perform a proper biscuit dance when your blanket is tucked in, what you need to be able to do is dance that blanket across the room unhindered. The Warden finds the extended version of the biscuit dance annoying because it's expressive (barking), do I call her interpretive performance(shimmy and singing) annoying, well yes, so I guess we're even.

There are risks to finding something good to roll in, the first rule is don't get caught, if they see you rollin' then there's a good chance they're gonna start sniffing around you, which is never a good thing. It's also a good idea to give yourself some room to roll, with your eyes closed, you're upside down, legs in the air, who knows where you'll end up. These are a few hazards of a good roll but don't be discouraged, keep on rollin', maybe this is how they discovered Rock and Roll!

title: Waiting for someone, anyone, to stop by is exhausting. Watching The Warden sweep the driveway is embarrassing so it's probably good that no one sees this. She's making sure I have a clean surface to stretch out while I'm soaking up the sun, wouldn't want to lay on a pebble or a blade of grass, what would the neighbours think.

media.title: Throwback to the early years when the family had high hopes that I could be trained to do menial tasks and tricks. Nothing can curve my enthusiasm when someone comes to the door, as one try's to hold me back while cracking the door open a smidge to offer a warning to brace yourself. Others may look at this as a failed attempt at training, I say they haven't tried hard enough, ever thought about putting a mini fridge by the front door stocked with aged cheese and roast, just saying.

I noticed a van parked in the neighbours driveway, the passenger was hunched over and wearing a hoodie, suspicious behaviour. I inched forward trying to assess the danger, could be a home invasion so I started howling, alerting the whole neighbourhood. The Warden immediately ran to the scene carrying a weapon (rake), turns out it was a repair company waiting for the homeowners. Better to be safe than sorry, the hunched over repair guy was on his cell phone, he was a little nervous about getting out of the van, he was assessing his danger.

Before I decide to get up I go through a series of yawns, at least ten in a row, it's a slow process. I'll do a few stretches while laying down, just to test my strength, moving too quickly is not recommended, might cause injury. Usually the first attempt to get up doesn't work, so I put my head down and wait for a more inspiring moment to move me, then I start the whole process again.

Some have said that I'm a little fussy, I'm really not, I have preferred choices. I like biscuits but only if they're gravy coated, it's a choice, I like all kinds of meat and I choose not to eat veggies. I prefer cheese and gravy over fruit, I prefer to exercise my rights to choose, I'm not fussy, I just know what I want, when I want it.

Royal Wedding hangover, watched the Wedding, then watched the highlights, not one mention of snacks, not even a cheese slice in sight. I did get to nap and later we had a Royal BBQ to celebrate the Wedding, after a little mingling and whining around the table I finally received a small serving of steak cut into itsy bitsy teeny weeny pieces, embarrassingly small, not a Royal portion.

Big event today, it's the Royal Wedding, there's a five hour delay here so I'm waiting for the announcement of the Royal Breakfast. The guests are arriving early so hopefully there will be snacks, they're probably wondering what will be served at dinner, for such a grand event there has to be roast simmering in gravy. Wake me when the bride shows up or when breakfast is served.

I had a fleeting thought about getting up but thankfully it passed. Every once in awhile someone will pass through the room all chipper and chatty trying to coax me into getting up, nice try but not happening. To be functional I require a full compliment of undisturbed sleep so ease on out and let the process continue.

title: Throwback to last year when I was denied access to the gardens, I was wrongly accused of interfering with the development of said plants. As you can clearly see these were mature plants and there was very little or next to no harm done, well maybe the odd leaf or so, nothing to get all riled up about. This year I'm hoping to gain some access to the gardens, no harm will come to the plants, trust me.

I got a new throw, technically The Warden has a new throw but I'm making better use of it. It's light, warm, soft and easy to yank off her chair, I also took it for a spin across the floor while barking at the same time. Even though it's a different throw I'm getting the same eye twitching results, go figure.

media.title: Guardian of the new plants, this is the first sign that the little ugly fences will soon restrict my access to the gardens. I'm hoping this year a portion of the garden will remain accessible, we are currently in negotiations, it's my Basset Rights to bury biscuits in a suitable location. I agree to not digging up new baby plants or laying on them if a section of older established plants remain open, it's a reasonable compromise.

It's BBQ season and the burgers were on the grill, so as I understand the drill the line forms behind me. I managed to be first in line because I was focused, there were regular burgers and cheeseburgers, at that moment it didn't matter to me, that's about the time when The Warden showed up, to make a long story short I did get a burger but was forced out of the line. This message was brought to you by Miss Lilly as her Monday Morning Reflections.

To the keeper of all that is good in the fridge, who has state of the art surveillance equipment, who entertains us with her shimmy and her unusual expressive singing style, I would like to wish The Warden a Happy Mother's Day. A helpful hint to enjoying this special celebration would be a small roast simmering in gravy with a cheese appetizer (just a suggestion).

I'm a victim of circumstances, I happened to yank my blanket off the bed and somehow got all tangled up in it, the rescue team was slow to react. I was totally covered in the blanket, I couldn't see and had to navigate my way into the other room by listening to voices, I also heard some giggling. Eventually dad removed the blanket but it took way too long and they appeared to be enjoying this way too much.
