Even if you are constantly under video surveillance it's still important to maintain your focus. Just a light coating of dirt over the biscuit, tamp it down, then walk away, try to be nonchalant, this is just a casual stroll through the destroyed Urban Jungle.

These are The Wardens 'fall' mitts, freshly washed and ready for the cooler weather. They are lightly stitched, slobber absorbent and now covered in hair which will add an extra layer of warmth. As a special feature they can be used to wipe up any wayward slobber slings which may occur on our walks, apparently not everyone appreciates a great slobber sling.

Gardening Tips By Miss Lilly. When preparing the garden before winter settles in it's important to turn the soil over, even if it's in a small space and hard to turn around. Clean around the bushes and at the same time check for possible biscuit burial sites. Never ever worry about a little dusting of dirt, focus on your task, take pride in your work and that person lurking across the yard, just ignore.

A spirited moment with the Furminator, this dance is actually quite similar to the Biscuit Dance. Having an outdoor platform I was able to do a little Free Style'n, showing off a few moves rarely captured on film. Also being outside there's a tendency to get a little distracted, once I hit the grass, nose down, it's game over, that's all she wrote, see you later alligator.

It's important after eating a biscuit on The Wardens blanket to clean up all the evidence. She gets a little riled up when I drag the blanket around the floor, especially after it's just been washed, but when you add biscuit crumbs, hair, slobber and an amazing aroma, then this truly becomes an eye twitching moment.

I've been told to stay away from this patch of newly seeded grass, no problem and I say the same to you, this is a protected burial site, newly buried biscuit. So now lower your weapon (rake) and slowly back away.

Fortune was raining down on me, I dug up a biscuit from outside and brought it in the house, I placed it on my blanket and was ready to do a biscuit dance when I heard this shriek. When The Warden saw the biscuit covered in dirt you would've thought it was a turd by the fuss she was making. She immediately replaced it with a clean biscuit and threw the prized one out, it just wasn't the same, there was no dance and the moment just sizzled out.

It takes time to select the perfect spot to bury a biscuit, there it is, fresh dirt topped with grass seed, yes this'll do. The Warden has been doing a little lawn maintenance lately, I of course help where I can, still after all my help she appears to be a bit edgy.

I'm sending a clear message to Friday the 13th, don't mess with the Legendary Urban Hunter Miss Lilly. This raccoon sang it's last song, well at least until the next attack. It's all about honing your skills, there's no graceful approach, you come in full force, grab the raccoon from the toy basket, find his music maker and make him beg for mercy or until The Warden comes running to see what all the commotion is about (she has issues).

Throwback to one of my last adventures in the Urban Jungle before The Warden got clipper happy. When I threw my tail up I was sending a message to The Warden, message sent but not received, she's a little slow on the receiving end but as you know she has issues. Right after this video was taken the Urban Jungle was destroyed, sad day, very sad indeed.

My preference is to be in the front yard, not stuck in the backyard where there's no action (except for the occasional brave critter). Now I must convince The Warden that it's in her best interest to relocate, because if Miss Lilly isn't happy then nobody's happy. If barking doesn't inspire the necessary change then I'll go sulk on the deck, that usually works, except lately she's taking her own sweet time.

Rarely captured on film, you will catch a rare glimpse of the Legendary Urban Hunter in action, stalking it's prey. Please be advised of the imminent danger, take note of the carefully calculated maneuvers, the total focus and what some may call the hunters dance with it's prey.

I'm thankful for many things especially when all the family is together. I'm thankful for the leftover gravy on my ear, the moments when I crash and bang into my brothers room to let them know I'm up, my own special serving of roast covered in gravy and the extra sniffing time on my walks. Happy Thanksgiving to everyone and may you all be as blessed and as fortunate as we are.

Apparently (go figure) I wasn't supposed to bury my biscuit here. There was fresh dirt, a sprinkling of grass seed, it was almost like a gift waiting to be opened. The Warden got all tied up in knots (again), it's an easy fix, nothing to get all stirred up about.

It's the official opening weekend of Gravy Season.  Today as part of the grand opening events we are scheduled to have a large roast simmering in gravy. As a special feature I'm expected to partake in a ceremony which will display my Gravy Dippers swimming in gravy. I'm hoping this year The Warden doesn't embarrass herself by chasing me around with a wet cloth, this kind of dampens the festivities, but as you know she has issues.

Take time out of your busy day (between naps) and enjoy laying in the dirt, it very therapeutic. One tip would be to remove the top layer of dirt, I find underneath it's cooler and has a fresh earthy smell. To get the complete full body experience it is highly recommended that you roll, all legs in the air and wiggle around. I don't worry about any clean up, The Warden is always lurking around looking for something to do.

Well there's one thing that's for sure, The Warden has maintained her amateur status as a gardener. Now it's time to bring in the A team, after an initial assessment and a little bit of digging, I've concluded that the soil is in perfect condition to bury biscuits.

title: Just reporting that all is safe and secure in the neighborhood, you don't need to always have your eyes open and looking around, all my other senses are activated and on high alert. At the slightest movement or sound I'll be all over it, the snoring, well, that's to camouflage my bolt-like spring-loaded action-packed movements, no sense wasting energy until it's required.

I'm amongst the ruins, my Urban Jungle has now become a barren wasteland. The clipper happy Warden let loose in the garden, she has created a path of destruction. After looking over the ruins I can now see the potential, plenty of room to bury biscuits, yes I have something to work with.

media.title: The Warden was giving me the look, you know the look that speaks volumes, it was zeroing in on my feet. It's just a little dusting of dirt, not enough to get all tied up in a knot about, chances are the dirt will rub off before I get up out of her chair, that's the good news.

title: I'm petitioning the Environmentalists out there to help save my Urban Jungle from being destroyed. The Warden needs to be stopped before she becomes a mad woman with clippers. This has been my little getaway, a place for great adventures and stories about the Legendary Hunter Miss Lilly. Please help save the jungle by signing the petition or by sending a cheese and deli basket, thank you for your support.

media.title: There I was just casually meandering along the perimeter of the yard when all of a sudden a squirrel bolted out of nowhere, he almost fell into the bushes as he scurried along the fence, I was slightly startled and gave a bit of a chase (minimal effort). Next thing I heard was this hissing sound, which was more startling than the squirrel, sure enough it was The Warden trying to send a message. The squirrel went up the tree, shaking its tail and then just stared at us, I think the tail shaking is the equivalent of the middle finger.

While we quietly wait and watch, some holding their breath, to see what ferocious predator is lurking in the Urban Jungle. Small critters shake and tremble at the sound of the ground quaking with each pounding step. After much anticipation the greatly feared Miss Lilly makes her presence known.

Throwback to yesterday doing it Basset Style. Rub-a-dub-dub two worms and a grub or should I say Shake Rattle and Roll, it was a productive day, ideal for rolling. I got a few yanks and a couple of 'hey hey get outta there', but the sun was shining, the lawn was calling my name and watch out, the slobber was flying.

I thought I wanted in until you opened the door but I'm sure I'll want in if you close the door. The Warden has issues with leaving the door open and I don't so we are at a standstill. Here's a hint, if I'm scratching at the door and it's covered in nose art I want in, it's not a grey area.

title: Excuse me, some assistance please, my blanket needs a little adjusting and try not to focus on the hair, we're outside and maybe the hair will blow off.  It's like the leaves that are falling from the tree, do you rake them every day or wait for the wind to blow them away. The Warden likes to rake the leaves every day that's why I worry about my blanket, holding the blanket up in the wind doesn't remove the hair, maybe if the leaves keep falling it'll distract her from my hairy blanket.

media.title: I'm shaking things up this Monday, gonna start this week off with a new attitude. If you wanna do a little shimmy then let loose (as long as Shimmy Shaking Mama abides by all restrictions), if you're inclined to nap then snooze away. It's your day, your choice, you choose, what will be will be.

The service has been great, just had my filtered water refreshed with ice, my blanket is laid out under the shade tree and the sun is shining. Eventually I'll meander into the sun, cop a few rays (aka nap in sun), sniff around for something roll worthy and then back to my blanket in the shade. Even though it's a strenuous schedule it's important to be vigilant, just in case someone walks by.

The end is coming near for this wilderness jungle, The Warden is setting her sights on chopping it all down. She's also filling in holes along the bottom of the fence with whatever's handy, I see there's the end of a broom, it's definitely a cry for help.

The lawn is a great place to roll with some wonderful smells, so here's The Warden pulling weeds out with no gloves on, I call this free style'n. I personally have no problem with this, actually I would request that she rub her hands all over me, I bet they smell real nice. Imagine one day she's picking up rabbit evidence with poop bags and the next day pulling weeds out with no gloves on, go figure.

Throwback to when I was trapped inside the little ugly fence. Not a lot of manoeuvre room but I can tell that this area has been violated by critters, there's a hint of bunny in the air, possibly a rogue chipmunk. I'm on the scene now and have secured the area, any perpetrators will be subjected to barking and a chase, beware.

If anyone asks you didn't see anything, not a thing. I've gotten a bit of a reputation for roughing up the gardens, not true, look at how gently I step around the plants, it's almost like I'm floating. There's also a biscuit buried under the last plant I checked, all's good.

No one was in danger at any time during this nap, The Warden might of teetered a tad but overall she maintained her balance and didn't interrupt me. I eventually had to stretch and rotate so she gained a little more leg room, also as a special note the moccasins make a nice headrest and are drool absorbent. We worked it out, it's all about a little give and take.

I have absolutely no intention of getting up, so slowly back away and I'll forget about this little intrusion. Well, there may be one thing that might inspire me to move, you know that block of cheese in the fridge, the one that's been calling my name, well be a good girl and go open that package, then you'll see what a true athlete is.

All clear, nothing to report, The Warden had a bit of a meltdown, there's evidence of an intruder in the backyard (rabbit droppings). I'll do a perimeter check while she confiscates the evidence (using poop bag). Well it's back to the surveillance room while she tries to figure out how we were infiltrated. I'll meander around the yard, catch a few rays while she tries to pull it together.

I met my friend Caboose on our walk, he's my height, short curly hair, small paws, tiny ears and about forty pounds lighter. I was bobbing and weaving ready to play, he ignored me, I did an impressive slobber shake, he wasn't impressed, the only thing left to do was put my nose to the ground and sniff, we finally found some common ground.

There was an incident with the laundry, the bed cover shrunk, which The Warden is indirectly attributing to me. I thought the cover was perfect the way it was, smelled nice, so what's a couple of hairs and a little dirt. It's an easy fix, all we gotta do is stretch it out, I'll yank on one end and The Warden on the other end, it's like a tug of war, keep pulling until it's back in shape. All this really proves is that doing excessive laundry can be hazardous, learn to adapt to your environment.

title: I just finished a little thing I call 'throw dancing', first you yank the throw to the floor, do a little four step around the room, all this to the accompaniment of some barking. Now to spice things up grab a biscuit, toss it on the throw and there you have the 'biscuit dance'. I must say it's a crowd pleaser, maybe you can't please everyone all the time, but don't let that dampen your spirit, I say dance on till you can't dance anymore.

media.title: The big news of the neighbourhood is I had a bath, The Warden likes to announce this tidbit to everyone, except no one really cares. I am no longer sniffable, no one takes an interest in some nice light flowery fragrance, it's boring. It may take a few days before I become memorable again, just imagine one of those smells that enter a room before you do, that's what I'm aspiring to.

I have asked that an arrest warrant be issued against The Warden and her accomplice (dad). Both are considered armed and dangerous, may be in possession of bath paraphernalia, for your own safety do not approach. I was taken against my will, put in the tub and tortured with smelly shampoo. With the help of a dead worm and a few good rolls I'm expecting a full recovery, in time. If you would like to help in my recovery please send a cheese and deli basket, express mail.

title: Big plans today, eventually, just working out a few details, because it's such a busy schedule I'm going to have to ease into the morning. I'll start the morning with a few stretches, maybe stand up and rotate, maybe. If you hear me snoring well that's just me grinding out some ideas, all this planning is time consuming and exhausting. I'd say by mid morning the plans will all come together and be ready for execution.

It won't be long before the chopping and hacking starts, I mean cutting and trimming of the plants begins, all this in preparation for the end of the season, The Warden has been selecting and sharpening her weapons. I'm just going to enjoy this jungle until this becomes a barren wasteland, once everything is cut down I'll be completely exposed to all the surveillance cameras and prying eyes.

media.title: I met our new neighbour, a nice lady with a knee length dress and high heels (from my view), she came running over for a greeting. A special note when meeting a Basset, plant your feet firmly on the ground and lean slightly forward, this helps prevent you from falling over when someone jumps up in their excitement. The nice lady didn't completely fall over, she teetered just enough for The Warden to apologize several times and say she's heavier than she looks.

With the fall weather comes the throws for the chair, love this time of year. Don't understand why The Warden keeps hiding these throws and then when she brings them out she places it at the top of the chair, it's a bit of a struggle but eventually I drag it off. She should really be thanking me for helping with the dusting the floor, it's all about giving back.

Here's really what happened, I was being one with nature in my urban wilderness, when suddenly just a few feet from my head a bunny hopped around the corner, The Warden shrieked, I popped up, it was a bit of a blur but I caught the scent, I must've sniffed every inch of the driveway and I left a warning message on the lawn. It was a brazen move by the bunny to hop this close to the danger zone, I'm sure next time he'll think twice before hopping around here again.

I'm adding this little morning adventure on the list of things not to do. I started out lapping up a bit of fresh water (without ice), then decided to explore and ended up with a complete shower. This is usually where The Warden comes running after me with a paper towel to blot me dry, but no, not this time.

I won't be able to join the kids this morning at the bus stop, first of all I won't be up, also The Warden wouldn't want slobber to get on anyone, especially first day back to school. Now if the bus could consider a later pickup, say mid morning, then I could join in all the excitement, if not then I'll just have to wait until the end of the day when everyone returns.

I saw movement over on the neighbours lawn, could be a chipmunk, I only have time for a quick investigation before I get the yank. You know the grass is greener on the other side and not as many yellow spots. Oh wait, there it is, the yank, that'll be The Warden trying to maintain a sense of control.

On my walk yesterday some lady stopped her car, got out and ran over to me, she said I was her dream dog. After introductions were made she got down on her knees and I received lots of kisses and scratches. The Warden didn't say one word about slobber or needing a bath, as far as this lady was concerned I was the complete package, a dream come true.

I have a very simple, uncomplicated method of asking to go outside, one scratch on the door means assistance please as I patiently wait for your arrival, once the door is open I may stretch and meander out. Two scratches in quick succession means let's go let's go, move it move it, no time to stretch or sniff the air. Now if there's three scratches your butt better be moving because this isn't a dress rehearsal and once that door is open I'm almost flying off the deck.

Caution, do not disturb, airing out and sunbathing in progress. All other lawn or yard work is restricted at this time, all hovering and lurking must be done at a safe distance (so I can't see you, bad vibes). The weeds underneath me will be accessible for removal when I do a stretch and rotate, all in good time.

I might get up but then again I might not, I don't do mornings. I'm more of a mid morning kinda girl, let's do brunch to get the day started, that's how I roll. Nice of you to stop by but if you don't mind I'm kinda busy right now.

title: I've been busy tending to the gardens, there's such a sense of freedom without the little ugly fences. Not to worry about the plants, no harm was done during the planting of my biscuit. The Warden is a little more relaxed now that fall is coming, she's sharpening up the clippers, now that's when the real destruction will happen.

media.title: Just a little extra grooming, I believe this should make up for any thoughts you may have about the 'B' word (bath). I've been doing a little extra work in the garden and feel I should be rewarded with one free pass on a bath. The Warden is making me suspicious though, she called me stinky, of course she said it in a little sing song lilting voice, maybe there's hope.

What do I love best when stealing a chair, the look on The Wardens face when she turns around and sees me nestled in. Her tea cup of coffee tinkling as she turns around making an attempt to sit, the roll of the eyes, the little huff and puff she makes, there's only one thing that can move me once I'm parked. Wait for it, wait for it, finally the crinkle of the cheese bag, oh yeah, great way to start the week.

The hair on the back of my neck indicates The Warden has spotted me, my Warden-detector is flaring up, or it could be the tip of my tail that's giving me away. What I need to do is find a denser section of the garden or locate the blind spot for these surveillance cameras.  As a side note does this angle make my butt look big, must be the zoom lens, we definitely need to invest in better equipment.

While helping to aerate the soil I found a bone I buried last year, all I have to do now is replant. Due to cooler weather and the fall creeping in the little ugly fence has been moved for better access. Looks like it's going to be a busy fall, I'm prepared to help The Warden with the yard work.

When you find yourself trapped in a compromising situation just calmly assess the situation and definitely don't make eye contact. I'm like a chameleon blending into the urban wilderness, The Warden has no idea where I am, so now the plan is to figure a way out before her motion detectors set off the alarms.

Throwback to yesterday when The Warden chased me around with a wet washcloth to clean the gravy off my ears. What's the point in having gravy dippers if you can't have a little gravy on them, first of all love the smell and later on there's a little snack readily available. As a side note a large dinner plate allows for maximum coverage for your gravy dippers.

I was third in line for dinner and got asked to step away, outrageous. I'm a family member and have rights, especially when there's roast and gravy. I was weak from hunger and had lost all hope when finally I was presented with a small plate (dessert size) with roast and gravy. It did make up for my exclusion and seclusion, I was once again reunited with the family and showered with affection, everything was right in my world.

title: Sometimes you have to do a little prompting in order to get the show on the road. I haven't got time to dilly dally, The Warden is giving last minute instructions, she might as well save it because once we hit the streets it is game on. My brother just follows my lead, straight out the door, sniff at every corner, then into the great Urban wilderness.

media.title: This brief interruption was brought to you by The Warden. I have no intentions of getting up and there should be a rule about interrupting ones sacred sleep time. Now back to my previously scheduled slumber.

There's been threats made against my outdoor blanket, The Warden is claiming it is beyond cleaning, might damage the washing machine. Well here's the good news, it doesn't need cleaning. Maybe just give it a flick in the air to scatter some hair or sit downwind if it bothers your delicate sensibilities. It's the perfect outdoor accessory while lounging and it needs to be left in its natural state.

title: Nothing should come in the way of your comfort, if the blanket is so rigid you could bounce a biscuit off it or the pillows against your back are poking at you, then make a few adjustments. You may have to dig a little to get the blanket just right, circle around a few times, knock the pillows on the floor but it's all in the name of comfort. Napping is an art form, it's about creativity and you are just expressing yourself.

media.title: There was another great escape on our street, the little white fluff ball of a puppy got lose, all I could do was watch from the cheap seats, The Warden wouldn't let me out to join the fun. The puppy was bobbing and weaving all over the lawns, people in bare feet chasing after him yelling 'treat treat', certainly sounds like the training is going well. The next level of training would be when they're chasing you yelling 'cheese cheese', all in good time he's still young. The puppy was finally picked up but the rescue team was exhausted, panting and smiling with relief.

Throwback to yesterday when I was captured on the surveillance tapes during my great escape. I had few options at this point, I was stranded in this Urban jungle with no way out, I had to ask The Warden for mercy and let me out. I might've lasted a bit longer if there were treats and fresh filtered water with ice.

title: I've escaped the confines of the secured premises, I'm now on the Lamb behind the little ugly fence. It's a jungle in there folks but I've tasted freedom, that is until my escape was caught on the surveillance cameras and The Warden showed up.

media.title: Watching The Warden do yard work is exhausting, she's chopping and hacking, I'm watching (supervising) and snoozing (tired of watching). The yard bag accidentally fell over so I might have dragged it around, there was a bit of a chase. It's important to remember to take a break and have a little fun, also as a side note, it's definitely more fun if the little ugly fences are removed during all yard work.

Motivational Monday, it's a new week so let's get this party started. I'm having visions of bacon, a nicely displayed cheese tray, later when all is quiet I'll be presented with a small roast covered in gravy. These pondering moments are brought to you by Miss Lilly, hopefully these moments will help get you through the day.

The Warden called me the Midnight Rambler, had to take care of a little business last night. I find there's a different pace you take in the dark shadows of the night, each step is measured as though you're stalking prey, or I'm just tired and meandering. Once I climbed the stairs back inside I patiently waited for my fresh filtered water with ice, a little nightcap before returning to my slumber.

title: Airing out is better than a bath, yes you heard it here and you can take that to the bank. Just make sure you expose the complete body, engulf the underside with the sweet light breeze, you'll be smelling like freshly laundered sheets drying outside, or if you wiggle around you'll get that great earthy scent with just a hint of worm.

media.title: The mail lady made a special stop today just to say hi to me, I might've howled, thumped my tail and wiggled around but she treated me like I was a special delivery. Of course The Warden was right on the scene making sure I didn't jump up, she always let people know I'm heavier than I look, which as you know can be a good thing, especially when there are predators in the sky looking to swoop and scoop.

While on our walk someone had commented on how fit I looked, The Warden replied, oh awww well, thank you. There seemed to be a bit of hesitation in the reply, I on the other hand except all compliments and relish in any adoration. They loved my soft silky ears until they ran into a bit of slobber, that's where the awkward moment comes in, the shuffling of the feet and wondering where to wipe their hands. It was a fleeting moment as I prance on knowing they can see how 'fit' I am.

I was in the sights of a local predator, he was high in the sky, great wing spread, flexing talons and laser beam eyes. I felt he was assessing his swoop and scoop ability, giving me the once over, I was low to the ground, slow moving, slight of stature (tendency to look smaller at great heights), well, he gave me a second look, shook his head and flew off. I'm sure he's a member of a local gang in the neighbourhood that's been giving us trouble, they're called The Crows.

The Art of Getting a Treat, this was me teaching my brother how to ask for a treat. First a couple of scratches on the distressed cabinet, a tiny light bark, throw in a little eye contact, and before you know it someone is getting you a treat. This method usually works, just don't try it twice in a row.

title: Before my brother left I took him for a walk, he's very accommodating and let's me decide the path we take, I like to go off the urban grid. A few blocks away there's an undeveloped section with some tree stumps and bushes, great sniffing and you still get Wifi. This area is not Warden approved, I like living on the edge.

It's great to have my brother home, we like to share the couch, this way I get to stretch out while receiving scratches. He also has no issues with hair to spare or dangling drool, and he doesn't even need a nudge to remind him I'm here and available. We just ignore The Warden hovering in the background, after awhile you get used to the twitching eye.

media.title: This was me waiting for my brother at the train station, I gave up the shotgun seat just for him, actually The Warden barricaded the front seat with her arm. I was able to stand out the window and give a howling Basset welcome, all these people just to see me, imagine. Eventually my brother showed up, he had no trouble finding us, I was like a beacon at the train station.

All systems are a go for my brothers return home this weekend. There's bacon in the fridge, a roast in the slow cooker and the cream cheese icing is ready to go on the cake. I was directly involved with the cream cheese icing, as soon as it was being cut up in the bowl I made an appearance, then I lingered until it was room temperature and ready for the beaters. For my involvement I got to lick both beaters and the spoon, I've taken over these duties since my brothers left home, one of the perks of being the only child at home.

Dog days of summer, I'm soaking up the sun before the rain starts up again. It's important not to wear my harness when sunning, don't want to get harness lines, also remember to rotate for full coverage. I'll do a little sun then move to the shade then back to the sun, it's a busy schedule and I'm exhausted after all this movement. The weather has been cooperating, it's cool in the shade and not too hot in the sun, making it perfect for spending time outside.

I came upon a particularly sniff worthy corner on my walk, of course I had to dig in and put the brakes on, I was leaning so hard to one side I almost fell over. There was an attempted yank and pull but this corner could not be passed up, and yes, I sniffed every blade of grass and up and down the tree several times. This was the ultimate message centre, I eventually got caught up on all the local news and before I left I sent a message of my own. We got home, eventually.

It seemed to be an early start to the day for some, it was reported that I was howling in my sleep, calling out to my ancestors from far away. Once dad bolted straight up with an adrenaline rush, he decided he might as well get up, I on the other hand slipped into his warm spot, curled into a little ball and returned to the zone. I'm not one for the dramatics like someone else, not mentioning any names.

Hello Monday, welcome to a new week, I'll be available for an official meet and greet probably later this morning. Hold all conversation and any chipper upbeat lilting utterances until I can gather strength. I need my full compliment of naps which turned into sleep then back to naps before I can face the day properly. Bare with me, you cannot rush a good thing.

I'm officially the assistant to the rookie arborist, The Warden is trimming trees and stacking the sticks in these precise, neat and tidy little piles. I just happened to be sniffing around and found a tasty stick near the bottom of the pile, did you know that if you yanked and ran with the stick the rest of the neatly stacked sticks would scatter all over the yard, go figure.

We had an intruder stalking around our house, I was immediately on full alert and poised for action. Out of the corner of my eye I saw the small lurking violator, fluffy, grey, red collar, pointy ears, with glaring eyes. I was ready, shoulders down, foot raised, in the attack position, when all of a sudden it became a blur and I didn't even have time to flex a muscle. It would have been a different story if the length of my line didn't limit my legendary hunting capabilities.

When I'm outside I like to set up my scratching station beside The Warden, she's good at multitasking, her one hand is completely devoted to me but every once in awhile she'll get distracted and a nudge or two is required. I do make an effort to reposition myself to get the full body coverage.

Throwback to when my brother last visited, where his scratches created piles of hair scattered all over the floor and a nice dusting in the air. It's the last time we had bacon, such a fond memory, all I can do these days is dream about bacon. We should start a tradition where every Thursday we celebrate with bacon, throw caution to the wind and just go wild.

Everything was going along fine, we were out for a sniff and stroll, when we got back home dad surprised me with a ride in the truck. Window down, ears flapping in the breeze, sniffing all the passing scents, we were headed to the pet store, still everything was fine, a little meet and greet along the way to the back of the store. That's when I suddenly realized, we were at the torture chamber, the smiling lady holding the nail clipping devices, I was at a point of no return.

Nothing better than a freshly washed blanket, corners nicely tucked in, all set for a little indoor activity. It's not the best scenario for burying a biscuit but if it gets The Warden riled up my mission is complete.

We have a rainfall warning today so I've asked the staff to notify me immediately when there's a break in the weather. Option two, have a helicopter on standby to take me somewhere dry, otherwise I'm not going out. My request for a yard canopy was denied so now they have to come with an emergency exit plan, my legs are crossed till then.

Snoring is a sign you're in the zone, it means do not disturb, you're riding the wave, just back away slowly and let sleeping dogs lie. Especially on a Sunday morning when it's dark and cloudy and there's not a hint of bacon in the air or a crackle of a cheese bag to be heard.

My favorite place to hang out is at the front of the house, that's where all the action is, plus it has a heated driveway (when sun is shining). According to The Warden I need supervision so I have to wait until she's available. This picture was taken by an amateur who has a lack of focus, at this angle the subject may appear a bit heavier than they actually are.

I had to help the family out again, I was on garbage watch detail, the crows were gathering around and chatting it up. They were conspiring to do a hit on our garbage until they saw me, so they moved their attention to the neighbours. All I had to do was spread out on the driveway and soak up the morning sun. The Warden says it about time to invest in a garbage can or it could be to prevent dad from parading around in his pjs and slippers.

The Warden has declared war, there's a fly in the house and she is armed with weapons of mass destruction. There's the rolled up paper, dish towel and the fly-swatter, let the games begin. I watched and waited, the fly was winning at this point, then it made one critical error, it headed for the lower part of the glass in the door. I stepped up and with one swoop I devoured the fly, that's how it's done, all The Warden had to do now was a little touch up on the glass.

Sometimes I like to separate myself from the crazy and just do some pondering, from here I can see the library (room with book shelves) and the hub of all major activity, the kitchen. If a freshly vacated chair becomes available I'm making my move, unless of course they are heading towards the fridge, when making these critical decisions it's important to conserve energy by resting your head, use only eye movements and be ready to pounce at a moments notice.

In order to protect the homestead you must show you mean business when securing the premises, this is my furious yawn, meant to be intimidating. I wasn't allowed outside for obvious reasons, The Warden tried tapping on the glass, wiggling the door handle, nothing was working until she resorted to her go to hissing, that scared off the bird. Actually I think all the birds started heading south and it's not even winter.

I was exhausted after meeting Luna, she's a Great Dane, I'd say I was about knee height. She laid down so we could do a proper greeting, I approached cautiously, she smelled nice. I laid down on my side thumping my tail, didn't want to scare her, I saw her checking me out, probably thinking I'm just a slip of a girl. Great to have big friends to put things in perspective.

New rule in the house, no more storing stuff in the closet that's not getting used, I decided to claim this blanket after I dragged it around. It looked like a clown car when The Warden started cleaning out the closet, I barked at things I've never seen before, it was a little traumatic and exhausting. Now I'll have to go downstairs and help reorganize the storage room, I might as well bring a biscuit, this may take awhile.

I was inches from the greatest capture ever, but as you can see I'm limited by the length of my line. This may be the rabbit that infiltrated our backyard, The Warden thought she had booby-trapped, I mean, secured the premises, but she found evidence (rabbit poop). They usually only make an appearance under the cover of darkness, that's when I'm sleeping, they know who they're dealing with, the relentless urban hunter.

Let's say it all started when a crow started pecking at the garbage, dad ran out in his pjs and slippers to scare it off, the only thing he scared was the neighbours. Then The Warden tried hissing at it, the crow look over its shoulder and if a crow could laugh that's what he did.  Finally they called in the A team, that was me, one look at me the crow flew away, my reputation precedes me, the legendary wildlife hunter (urban wildlife only). I saved the family once again from any additional cleanup.

Throwback to when they thought it would be a great idea for me to sleep in a small bed, not one of their better ideas. Oh I'd nap in the little bed, maybe drag it around, but when the lights are out and everyone else goes to bed, that's when I prefer to sleep in the middle of a queen size bed. It started out with a little whimper, that's when they caved and lifted me up on the bed, there was no looking back after the first lift.

It's really hard to be a great legendary hunter when you're tethered to a tree, while all around you the wild animals are fleeing from your mighty presence. For example, there's a chipmunk (urban wilderness) under this bush showing no fear at all, it would be a totally different story if I was set free, wouldn't it chippy!

I got to spend some time with the sprinkler system guy, he was on the ground doing a small repair and he didn't mind that I was in his personal space. At least that's what he told The Warden when she started fussing about me being in the centre of everything. He was a friendly chap even though he had no treats, from the smell of him I'd say he was the owner of a fairly large dog with short hair, he also said I had a lot of personality.

It's cloudy, it might rain and it's Monday, therefore chances of me getting up are slim to none. My perfect Monday would be, bright sunshine, sizzling bacon, the sweet sounds of the cheese bag opening, fresh filtered water with ice and eager hands ready for a day of scratches. Until then I'll just wait it out on my queen size bed.

A miracle cure has been found for getting rid of the nose holding smell from my harness, so eloquently put by The Warden. You put the harness in a bucket, sprinkle with baking soda, add warm water, then a cup of vinegar, let soak for 15 minutes and finally rinse with cold water and let dry. I smelt nothing after the harness was dry but I guess that's the point, no offending sweet flowery or lavender smell.

In order to truly appreciate natures beauty it would be more meaningful if I was on the other side of this little dinky ugly fence. A place where I could mingle, gently step around these delicate creations and bury my biscuits. As a side note something is eating the tops off the little flowers and if the fence was removed I could help with the weeding, just saying.

I was helping dad with the yard work, he added some new soil and grass seed in certain areas, then I'd lay on it and roll. It's a new technique, a form of tamping, this is to ensure the dirt and seed are firmly planted. Of course The Warden had an opinion on this new technique, all I heard was blah blah blah.

Throwback to the early years when I wasn't allowed on the furniture, even though I needed help to get up and down. This is where chapter one of The Wardens Book of Rules began, little did we know it would grow into a library. Today, The Warden helps me up on the queen size bed, even though we started out with no sleeping on the bed, I think I've trained her well.

Just adding a fresh layer of sweet rolling aroma, always important to keep it topped up. I thought I was having a private moment, that's when I noticed the surveillance cameras honing in on me, nothing going on here, just move along.

If I'm looking a little slimmer, less fluffy, it's because of all the extra scratches and walks I had from my brother over the holiday weekend. I'll be recovering today while The Warden gathers up all the remnants left from the scratches, she'll be busy but it's good therapy, did I happen to mention she has issues.

I showed my brother all the great places to sniff during our walk, it's not about how long you walk, it's about the quality of the walk. It's also early and a holiday so wearing pjs is quite acceptable in the Urban setting.

Having my brother home is great, I immediately went to his room this morning, did a crash and bang to see if he was up yet, well he wasn't, but is now. We'll hang together, give him a chance to continue his scratching sessions while we wait for bacon. Later we'll go for a sniff and walk, while The Warden sneaks in a quick once over (first round of hair detail).

Happy Canada Day!  How about we celebrate all weekend long eh!  There's nothing better than starting the day off with bacon, maybe later on have a BBQ hamburger, of course if it's no trouble, please and thanks. Always important to be polite, especially on Canada Day ð¨ð¦

It's hard to have a quiet morning stroll when you've got a noisy bird yapping the same tune, not to mention the surveillance cameras watching your every move. Maybe the cameras could notice the ugly fence, the garden would be greatly enhanced if they were removed, just saying.

Throwback to when my brother was last home, we were discussing the Art of a Great Scratch. He was a quick study, very little nudging required, after a good scratching session hair would be dancing in the air, the blanket would be layered with hair and The Warden would be hovering politely in the background (eye twitching).

It's the little things in life that give special meaning, like stealing a chair just as The Warden was about to sit down. She picked up her book which was reserving her chair, got distracted for three seconds, that's when I made my move, one bounce and I was all nestled in. I cherish these moments, now wait for it, the sigh, the look and finally, 'oh brother would you look at that', my job is done.

Well I got a bath on a technicality, I was in the backyard, meandering, when I came upon a delightful smell, I dipped down and went in for a roll. Did I happen to mention that the grass was also wet, so this created a great combination, a heavenly smell with just a hint of wet dog. My bath contract became null and void if a combination was used, hence the technicality.

Monday's should come with a caution, prepare to ease into the day, motivation at a standstill, bribery and incentives highly recommended if any movement is required. It's probably best if you just move along, nothing to see here, don't call me I'll call you, see you on the flip side.

Sunday mornings are a quiet time, a reflective moment, a soft kinda lullaby, a bacon sizzling sound, a laid back and nod off thing happening, but then everything changed. It started with a gentle head bobbin, a shoulder roll, then the arms were flailing, hips were moving and a shimmy broke loose, it was a Proud Mary Moment.

This is me out in the wilds, coping with the elements, on the front steps laying on a slab of concrete. It's called roughing it, being tethered to the snowblower with no blanket, no pillow and no fresh filtered water with ice. It's also called building character, knowing I can survive the hard times.

If you're looking for me today look no further, I'll be right here, at least until the rain stops. We're going to have thunderstorms and rain all day, it'll be one long snooze fest. Of course I'll get up to stretch, rotate, steal a chair and look outside from time to time but I'm definitely not getting wet. I'll sleep through the thunderstorm, it's just background noise, it'll mix in well with the snoring.

It's a jungle out there my friends, I noticed the neighbour added a new lawn ornament, it appeared to be a full grown lion. I approached with caution, as you would with a lion, tail down, staying low to the ground and inching forward. In order to get close I had to slink past a few lawn gnomes, it's like they were closing in on me so I backed out, the whole experience was eerie, I had raised hackles, it was definitely a sign to move on. I'll be giving this lawn a wide birth, you could feel all eyes watching as you pass.

We changed our walking route and explored new territory, this is where my sniffing shifted into high gear. I was forced to almost run through this one section that was covered in goose poop, at least that's what the tour guide (aka The Warden) said it was. Apparently we'll be avoiding this part of the tour on all future outings, where's their sense of adventure, they need to stop, sniff, drop and roll, live life to its fullest.

Just because I'm outside roughing it doesn't mean I don't like to have a few comforts, I think ice water should be a standard, fresh filtered water with ice, refreshed when ice melts. Only if it's not too much trouble, you know, while you're up fussing around you might as well be doing something useful. Of course, thank you in advance for your thoughtfulness.

I was inches from counter surfing last night but then The Warden caught me, apparently it's not polite behavior in front of guests. As a side note, the counters are not Basset friendly (too high) and I was just getting a sniff, actually some of the guests found it amusing. After much mixing and mingling, maybe a whine or two, I did receive a small tidbit of sausage. It just seems like a whole lot of work for the tiniest of rewards.

This is my dad trying hard to convince me to get up and join the world. I'm thinking about it but I'm waiting to hear a few key words. Of course this being Father's Day we should start the day off right with a big breakfast, then lay around in pjs and watch golf all day.

I was out in the wilds (front lawn) trying to blend in with the environment (rolling), when I happened to see a small stalking creature, it had it's prey locked in its eyes, slithering past the neighbours car (urban wilderness), on the hunt for a chipmunk. This creature is very rare and seldom seen in our area, easily identified by their quickness and they ooze a sense of danger. The Warden of course holds me back and warns me not to mess with cats.

Thank you all for the Birthday Wishes yesterday. The Warden and I spent the afternoon outside where I was given non stop scratches while I lounged, very little nudging required. There was a little fuss after about having to use a nail brush but that was to be expected with her issues. Dad made me a BBQ hamburger, cut into small bite size pieces, as per instructions from The Warden. There was no garden access but the scratches made up for it, it was a great day.

It's my 5th Birthday today, I'm not expecting a big bash, no need for a Party Planner but you can keep the Catering Service and the Cheese Fountain with Bacon Sliders. I do have a Birthday Wish though, open access to the garden so I can bury several of my gravy coated biscuits. I'm just a simple girl, nothing fancy, low maintenance, you would hardly know I'm around.

Well it happened, I was out in the yard taking care of business when all of a sudden the sprinkler came on and blasted me. There's a couple of problems here, first of all it's wet (counting this as a bath), secondly, when one is in the midst of personal affairs it's needs to be done without interruption. Note to dad, make others aware when you are testing the sprinkler system.

I had an interesting walk, saw a little boy pulling a little dog on a leash, the dog had plastic wheels. He had no personality, carried no scent, so I kept a cautious distance and waited until he passed. Once he rattled on I tried to pick up a scent but came up empty, must be one of those  new designer toy breeds.

I can think of no greater way to start the week than to steal a chair, it's a sign of good things to come. Especially if there's a little huffing and puffing, the eyes twitching, and then finally the walk to the kitchen. Yep, the fridge door opens, the crinkle of the cheese bag and here she comes, oh surprise, is that for me, as I'm licking my lips in anticipation, a great start to the week indeed.

Just couldn't pass up an opportunity for a good roll, I happened upon something that smelled roll worthy, could've been a worm. You gotta lean into the roll, use your back legs for momentum and wiggle around making sure you get maximum coverage. Oh yeah, I'm feeling fine and smelling great.

Even if I can't see The Warden I know she can see me, I can feel those beady little eyes following me all over the yard. Okay, maybe once or twice I was in the garden but it's time to move on, get over it, come out of your dark little surveillance room and put down your motion detectors, nothing to see here.

This is me getting lectured on doing something I shouldn't, like being in the garden. It's important to listen, make eye contact and be sympathetic to their position, at the same time all you hear is blah blah blah.

I got up way too early, The Warden thought it was a good idea if I helped take the recycle out. As I was turning around I knocked a bin over which set off a double bark/yawn combo, it was too early to just bark but the situation required an attempt. How early was it?  Too early to pee, now that's early.

Rainy day activities for me is hitting the snooze button, for The Warden it's some extra cleaning (go figure). Apparently while cleaning the library (room with book shelves), she found a biscuit amongst the books, while this set off a flurry of activity, probably because it wasn't filed under B. Order was eventually restored once the shelf was cleared off, cleaned and then the books replaced to their original order.

I've got nowhere to bury my biscuit, the garden has been secured, but not to worry this is where I have to get creative. The Warden may have won this round but she had to bring in a Security Consultant in order to do it. I still have around the deck and planters to consider.

I'm not allowed behind the chair so this little table was put there to block my access. If you do a little push and nudge, then slide along the bookshelf, you'll find yourself in the winners circle. Barking helps to keep you motivated and focused, also gets you the desired attention from The Warden.

title: I've received a stern warning, I'm no longer allowed to scratch at the old distressed cabinet behind me. There used to be treats on top of the cabinet but The Warden decided to move them to another location. I thought we had an understanding, I would scratch the cabinet, The Warden would come running and I'd get a treat, until now, she definitely has issues.

media.title: You just gotta believe, if there's a will there's a way. With all your support and encouragement I was able bust through the ugly fence.  As you noticed only two flowers were slightly moved and I needed assistance to get out of the garden. The Warden is coming along nicely, should be able to receive visitors later today.

I was doing the biscuit walk around the perimeter, looking for a gap in the garden fence, which is still ugly by the way. As I was walking I kept looking up at the window and there she was, The Warden, watching my every move. As I was approaching the end of my search I noticed the planter, full of dirt, no plants and most importantly accessible. I jumped up, started digging, dropped the biscuit in, then buried it with my nose. The look on The Wardens face was well worth the effort.

It's very difficult in our house to surf the counters, it's a design flaw, they wanted high ceilings and counters, not very accessible. Except for today, dad dangled a piece of turkey sausage (extra lean) over the edge, he turned his back then I made my move, I snatched it and ran like hell to the mat. Of course dad set this up because he finds it funny when I'm own a mission, the pounding of my paws as I make my escape with the forbidden bounty.

Just imagine you're in a dark small room, it's quiet (because I stopped barking), your all alone, there's no sign of a rescue team, well, that was me trapped in the wine cellar (aka closet). Then I heard my name, along with a small lecture about locking myself in the cellar. What can I say, the door was open and I took advantage of the moment, someone also might want to review their response time in the event of an emergency, just saying.

A lot of excitement around here, there was a raccoon in the neighbours tree, The Warden claiming it was the size of a small bear. Dad ran out in his pjs and slippers, I followed behind him with my nose to the ground, I could sense danger in the air, also I had some exposed biscuits to worry about.  The Warden was like a tour guide, pointing and giving the highlights, of course all this could be seen on the surveillance cameras.

Usually The Warden prepares the couch for me, she'll remove the pillows at the end then reserve her two thirds. Well she didn't this time or else I was early, so I plowed the pillows off the couch, easy to do, nose down, catch the bottom corner, then just a flick over the edge. It was now a clean slate, so I settled in and then when The Warden showed up I made my move, I made a subtle move up the side to her two thirds, she can be a little needy at times so I try to be there for her.

title: The Warden just kept reading her book, so I had to continually nudge her to scratch me. I figure if you're just sitting there you might as well be productive, you don't need two hands to read. There was a nice breeze, I had some great scratches and hair was tumbling all over, a sign of a good quality scratch. When The Warden finally glanced at me all she said was 'oh for heaven sakes', now why would she say that.

media.title: The Warden is looking for me, I'm hidden behind a table where she has forbidden me to be. She has blocked off all access and it's taken me a few tries, but I found if I scrunch across the lower bookshelf, slide around a small table, slither behind the chair, then bingo, I'm now where I want to be, in the forbidden zone, it's all about seizing the moment.

Dad was outside with some stranger, lurking in the bushes, pointing at the gardens.  I should be out there, I know everything about the gardens and bushes, where the best spots to roll or to bury something. Eventually I was let outside, before someone called the help line.

title: Love the sun, this was yesterday, while The Warden and I sat out front. Sitting out front means I can keep an eye on any movement while at the same time catching a few sun rays. I like to feel the warm breeze wash over me, or as The Warden so elegantly puts it, blows the stink off me.

media.title: We had an exciting few moments, I noticed the gate open and took off running, this certainly got everyone's attention. Next thing I notice is dad running up the street calling my name and saying 'cheese cheese'. I ran to the neighbour lady who was looking for attention, she fussed over me until dad showed up. Dad thanked her, assuring her I was friendly as he put my harness on and dangled a piece of cheese in front of me. The Warden said I looked like a show dog, prancing, stepping lightly, head held high, as I followed the cheese home.

The ugly fence came down when they were adding more earth, this is where I made my move. I quickly found a biscuit and buried it, nothing like fresh dirt, very little digging required, just move the dirt around with the nose. After it's buried just nonchalantly walk away, don't make eye contact.

Dad squealed on me, I dug up a biscuit from the planter, ran inside with it, placed it on my blanket, prepared to do a biscuit dance when all of a sudden Dad snatched up the biscuit and threw it out. The Warden would've at least tried to wash off the mud and dirt, pat it dry and then give it back. Dad did offer two replacement gravy coated biscuits but then told The Warden about the whole incident.

I no longer have access to my burial sites (aka garden), The Warden put up this dinky unattractive ugly fence, which is just high enough to keep me out. Last year I was able to shoulder my way through a couple of spots but this year she tightened the gap. Never say never, I'll be inspecting every inch of this barrier waiting for an opportunity, wish me luck.

I don't mind special treatment when I'm on my walk, a lady up the street comes running out with a big bowl of fresh water whenever she sees me, the bowl is large enough to dangle both ears in. She comes to me with a sweet lilting voice and calls me her Lilly, this is where I'll lay down so she can fuss over me.  Dad says I'm just taking any opportunity to rest, while that's partly true, but I also enjoy the personal service.

Well she did it, The Warden put tick and flee stuff on my neck and back. I've already rolled all over the yard, looking for something good to roll in, there wasn't anything, so now I'll try the flower beds. The Warden knew I was mad so she stayed back until I stopped huffing and puffing, then I just laid in the sun.

The sunny weather has arrived, I'll be soaking up the sun, rotating between full sun, shade and the driveway, and at all times waiting and watching for any movement. Another sign of great weather is The Warden wearing pedal pushers (no tassels), I'm also recommending some seasonal grooming.

I met a new friend on my walk, Sofie, she was about the size of my head, so I laid down to do a formal greeting. I could sense a bit of an attitude, a little standoffish, and I even had a very enticing worm fragrance, which I thought deserved some notice, she didn't even do a sniff or a walk around, definitely an attitude.

There was a slight incident, The Warden made butter tart squares for a luncheon and then she noticed dad eating some, that's when she discovered they were all gone. Being an old football coach dad immediately went on the defence, rookie move, The Warden is a seasoned player, one look and it was game over. Good news is I got to lick the crumbs from the second batch that got made in time for the luncheon.

Starting a new week means starting with a clean slate, all past indiscretions have been erased from The Wardens logbook, I hope. Maybe she'll overlook how I was able to steal her chair when she got up, not once but three times in a row.  There was an obstacle, her book, but I found if you circle around a number times it could somehow, accidentally fall off.

Today is a special day for mom, may she have lots of shared treats, extra naps and droolery. It's a judgement free day for all shimmy shakers, you'll be applauded, so set those tassels on fire. Also The Warden can relax, no judgment, go ahead and check the furniture for buried biscuits, any you find are yours today. Thank you mom for making my every day so special.

Due to rain today I'll be reflecting on the good ole days of yesterday. The Warden and I spent the afternoon outside pulling weeds out of the lawn, my role was more of an overseer. She'd toss a clump of freshly turned earth with weed attached, plus the added bonus of a worm wiggling out, it was an opportunity I had to seize, so I rolled on it. The Warden said I now smell like dirt with just a hint of worm, the perfect combination that should linger on for days.

Indoor activities can vary depending on the reaction of others, if they're slow to react then I'll take it up a notch. Usually barking gets a good response and then I have their full attention. Now if someone gets up from their chair, I have a choice to make, do I immediately steal the chair, continue ramping it up or wait to see if they head to the kitchen, usually the kitchen gets my attention.

There I was enjoying just a little me time, having a much needed snooze, when all of a sudden I heard this screeching, banging, rustling noise. Oh, it was just Shimmy having another Proud Mary Moment, these moments are often unpredictable, yet still startling (not recommended for most viewers). I've noticed that the tassels don't bounce like they used to.

I got accused of leaving muddy paw prints on the floor, I beg to differ, what I saw was size 7 tasseled slipper prints. Of course it's all circumstantial now, The Warden was quick to cleanup all evidence. If I'm ever charged I would like to present my case to a jury of my peers, all jury members would receive a complimentary cheese and deli gift basket, just as a thank you in advance.

I'm helping in the kitchen while mom makes morning muffins, not to be confused with afternoon or evening muffins, helping means staying out of the way but keeping an eye on what's coming out of the fridge. Sorry to report no cheese or bacon was used in the making of these muffins, just oatmeal. Once they are in the oven there's no sense hanging around for the cleanup, timing is everything.

All regularly scheduled activities are cancelled until further notice or until it stops raining. Getting wet is no longer an option, even though I've been creative with drying off techniques. Sliding along the couch is always popular, rolling in the bed sheets is the best if I can get a lift and let's not forget about yanking the throw on the floor and giving it a spin around the room. Of course there's always my personal assistant (aka The Warden) ready with the paper towel pat down.

The Warden had her raincoat on and my leash in her hand in order to convince me to go outside, otherwise I was staying inside with my legs crossed. It was a light rain but still considered wet, and yes, I'm adding this to my list of baths taken this year. One recommendation, a heated luxury towel while gently rubbing and uttering sweet nothings.

I stood at the back door twice, saw the rain and said forget it, I don't do rain. The third time, The Warden opened the door, gave me a gravy coated biscuit and out I went into the elements (aka light rain). I quickly buried the biscuit, did my business, then right back in. Greeting me at the door was The Warden, with paper towel in hand getting ready to pat me down. It's gonna rain for four more days, hope there's lots of paper towels.

Mom had a bucket of leaves and small sticks, just sitting there on the deck ready for recycling. Did you know that if you yanked one of the sticks out the whole bucket would spill over, well go figure, that's exactly what happened. There was a bit of a chase during the cleanup, a little bobbing and weaving, who knew that cleanup could be so much fun.

Throwing it back to yesterday, before the betrayal. Dad and I had set out in the truck to pick up the lawnmower, when all of a sudden he took a detour to the Pet Store, all was going well, I was doing the meet and greet, actually dad said it was like I was a Rockstar, people lining up to see me.  Then it took a bad turn, I was at the gates of hell, a lady with nail trimmers in one hand and my leash in the other hand, leading me into the torture chamber.

I was going for the casual wind swept look and hoping my girth wasn't too distracting. Sometimes certain pictures can take on a life of their own, in just one frame you're thinking maybe better cut back on the snacks, another frame you're just a slip of a girl who's got it going on. Let's just consider this angle as my fluffy side.

ð¶Every move you make, every bite you take, I'll be watching you ð¶. I'll admit it, I'm a watcher, each and every bite, now let's say it was aged cheese, then I'm an incher, I'll inch in real close. Drooling will occur, can't be helped, there's an occasional whine, who wouldn't, and yes I'll even nudge if for some reason I'm not noticed by now. It's considered an art form, which you to can develop with practice, commitment and intensity.

Monday's are really about recovering from the weekend so let's consider this a non productive day. I'm gonna start out slow and steady, then mellow out into the afternoon, maybe do a rip and tear early evening, at this point I just don't know, I'm just gonna go with the flow.

This little thing is called a headband sling, so where's all the kisses now, this is almost like when Shimmy Shaking Momma wears her retro headband, everyone just backs up slowly not making eye contact.

I put the family on notice, no floating objects allowed in the house, so they sent it outside where it was bobbing in a threatening manner. Eventually it had to be completely removed from the premise, for the safety and tranquility of the family.

The Warden has come up with some new tactical maneuvers, I can't have my gravy coated biscuits until after I come in from outside. In the good ole days my four rationed biscuits would be lined up on my treat mat, then when I eventually got up I would meander and stretch my way to the door, do a quick inventory of my food and biscuits, all this on my way outside. Well lately, I would do a snatch and grab of a biscuit and head outside to bury it. This should really be considered exercise and a little encouragement would be greatly appreciated, plus a replacement biscuit.

A true sign of spring is not only seeing the plant and trees bloom, it's washing windows and putting in the screens.  I helped, I barked at the screens, like who wouldn't, they were stored in the wine cellar (aka closet) over the winter, then brought out and placed in the windows. Spring cleaning tip, always refresh (aka clean again) the screens before placing in the windows and never leave the paper towels where they can be snatched up and shredded.

Always remember to tamp down the top soil once the biscuit is buried, Biscuit Burying Technique 101. The real highlight is when The Warden comes running out near the end, then she huffs and puffs, another successful mission.

I was expecting a walk, had my harness on, heading towards the door when all of a sudden we took a detour to the bathtub. I wasn't scheduled for a bath until 2019, if you remember I was given a pass in 2018 because I got wet in the rain, they completely violated my bath treaty. Now mom says I smell like a wet dog with just a hint of lavender.

Mom is trying to decide on what sign to hang on the door, 'Beware-Dog Shedding, Enter At Own Risk' or 'Hair To Spare, Help Yourself' or 'Shedding Season, A Gift That Keeps On Giving'. Oh she has a lot more, she's just getting started, but offering a lint brush to each guest may be a bit much.

I achieved the almost impossible, I buried all four of my rationed biscuits in the garden. I snatched up the first one on my way outside and when I came back in I noticed The Warden was in the kitchen, that's when I made my move, in and out until all the biscuits were buried. You gotta love the open door policy, so much can be achieved without barriers.

I found a leather glove on my walk, I approached with caution, circled around, inched in, then did the sniff and snatch. Once I took ownership I shook the glove and ran in circles, this glove was definitely a keeper, I applied the Basset rule, finders keepers. That's when The Warden stepped in, she took 'my' glove and hung it on the fence. There's a basic principle that should apply, if you find a glove in the spring it's yours.

All I heard was The Warden yelling rabbit rabbit, I ran outside, spotted the rabbit, then gave chase. Of course I had to stop abruptly, put the nose to the ground and start tracking. I have to rely on their scent because rabbits are just a blur, there one second, gone the next. This would be considered a hunting success story, I have captured their scent to memory and cleared the yard of all intruders.

Throwing it back to when I thought it was time to get creative and buried my biscuit in the fireplace grill. My definition of buried means it's private and a secret, but no, The Warden had to parade everyone in to view my new burial site. They were milling about, chatting and taking pictures, all which completely destroyed the true essence of the burial ritual.

What a fuss The Warden was making, I dug up a garden biscuit and brought it in the house, yes it was covered in dirt but that's what you get from a freshly dug biscuit. She snatched it up quickly, then took it to the sink and washed it, the earthy flavour was somewhat diminished, now it's just a plain scrubbed clean biscuit.

It was a late night, we stayed up to watch hockey, there was a lot of hooting and hollering, possibly a shimmy or two, and I celebrated with a biscuit dance. I really think that if 'The Leafs' are in the playoffs we should have cheese, bacon and gravy, for each and every game.

One final belly rub before my brother leaves. Try not to focus on the piles of hair scattered around the floor or the light dusting in the air, all remnants of a great scratching session. The Warden is looking rather relaxed, except for that one twitching eye, with a little vacuuming later she'll be just fine.

Happy Easter my friends!  It's great when my brothers are home and it's not just because there's gonna be bacon, as they say, bacon is the glue that holds the family together, ancient basset saying. I'm also hopeful that my gravy dippers will be covered today, I just gotta believe.

It's great having my brothers home for the weekend, to make them feel at home I did a crash and bang into their rooms, just as a good morning welcome.  I also brought a biscuit as a gift, we can dig it out of the sheets later. It's nice to start the morning off with everyone getting up early, that way we can spend a little time together before my first nap.

Two people on our walk said it looks like I've gotten bigger, mom and dad looked at each other and said, you think so.  Now I'm a topic of conversation, one lady quickly retracted and said she meant longer, the other lady said it's because she hasn't seen me in awhile. They were probably looking at the wrong angle, I do have curves and at certain angles I'm really quite slim.

Timing is everything, mom says I have a real knack for showing up at the exact moment when the good food comes out of the fridge. She took out the aged cheese and I was her new best friend, up close and personal friend. I licked the crumbs from her hand and left a nice shiny glossy sheen, it's equivalent to a basset moisturizer.

I howled for a reason, the neighbour was raking the yard, of course guess who came running, The Warden. She said the whole neighbourhood heard me, which was the point, to sound the alarm when there's action on the street.  While now that you're here, maybe we could have a snack and discuss howling protocol.

I met a new friend, Cinder, he's a giant Newfoundland, he has nice knees.  He laid down as I inched closer, I sniffed, he sniffed, it was all good. When he stood up I showed him a few moves, bobbing and weaving, he didn't seem impressed but his mom was. She also said I was short, had rather long ears and a wonderful personality, overall I think I made a great first impression.

Monday's are about starting fresh, wiping your slate clean, all indiscretions are a thing of the past, a faint memory. Forget the worm rolling incident, the smell will eventually fade or the kibble burying fiasco, all so long ago, hardly worth mentioning. As you can see I've moved on, let's hope The Warden can do the same.

Rule number 3,648, volume 8, subsection 3:  if you bury one of your rationed biscuits outside, it does NOT get replaced with another one. Therefore, do I fake bury it inside, then eat it, or do I take it out to the garden, dig a hole and really bury it. What will help decide will be whether or not I can slip pass The Warden with the biscuit, then head outside to the garden, getting one up on The Warden always wins out.

Talk about luck, on the driveway I noticed a few worms just laying there, I glanced first at The Warden to make sure she was distracted, then I did a sniff and dip. It was during the second lean into the worm that I got the yank, talk about a lot of fuss over one worm, that's when I noticed the second worm. For the record it was not gross or yank worthy.

I found something extra special in the laundry, The Warden was spring cleaning the doilies, who would've thought these delicate little things could be so fragile. There was a bit of a chase, some tugging back and forth, and then The Warden just gave up, I guess doilies aren't made for fun, nothing that a little tape, glue or staple can't fix.

title: The Warden has come up with a new strategy, she has removed several triggers that stimulate questionable behaviour, I'm draped in one of those triggers. I've been known to yank these throws off chairs, drag around while barking, then perform a biscuit dance, all this without charging admission. She's also 'trying' to block off access to the floor air vent, it provides great acoustics while barking. There's one simple solution to all this, in one word, 'cheese'.

media.title: Let's go outside they said, sounded like a good idea at the time, then it started raining. We got as far as the mailbox when I made the decision to turn around and I wasn't taking no for an answer. It was a run back to the house, no sniffing no nothing, but it was too late, I was wet and I couldn't shake it off. Now you know this does count as a bath even though I wasn't scheduled for one this year.

I finally had my first spring roll, all legs in the air and doing the full body squirm. Yes, I was wearing my freshly washed harness, so everything is right on course. While sniffing around I came upon this marvellous smell, I put my shoulder down and leaned into it, by this time it was too late for the yank, so The Warden just let me go. Welcome to spring and all it has to offer.

It's a rough start, dad said my harness stunk to high heaven and The Warden washed it.  Just another victim fallen to this senseless washing, almost as bad as a bath. Who goes around sniffing someone's harness, definitely not my friends, actually I don't think they even notice my harness when they're sniffing me. Not to worry it'll be right as rain in a few days, or should I say 'ripe' as rain.

title: The Warden had a great idea, why not put some paper towel on the mat for her boots, it would save cleaning up all the wet grass. Seemed like a good idea until I noticed it, definitely out of place, then I had a great idea, I snatched it up, ran with it and finally shredded it. Some ideas are better than others, I had fun, The Warden, not so much.

media.title: Mom woke me up to look at the sheep in the front yard, that's when I heard the cackling, it's April Fools. There was no sheep and only one Fool. Every year it's the same thing, some different animal grazing in the front yard, I have to look, just in case. For this spotlight moment of April's Fool (aka mom) I got a piece of aged cheese.

Just because I ate my full bowl of food The Warden did an extra check in the furniture to make sure I didn't hide any food in the cushions. Where has the trust gone, I'm under constant surveillance after the last incident. She pretends to be straightening the cushions as she slips her hand down along the couch and chair, these locations have been compromised, it's time to change strategy and come up with an alternative plan.

title: We are having a small celebration to honour the good times of moms old flannel pjs, which have been taken out of rotation (aka thrown out). If you would like to contribute may I suggest a small roast or some aged cheese. I will share some memorable moments where I've curled up next to the warm, frayed and ripped pjs, oh the good times.  All are welcome.

media.title: Go ahead with your fussing and cleaning, I'll be here if you need me. Sometimes it's all about just being supportive, besides I'm in a hair and slobber free zone.  I'm really protecting my blanket from a senseless washing, it's just perfect the way it is, it has that lived on feeling and the smell is something dreams are made of.

Sometimes you just have to try a little harder to get results, this burial site didn't quite work out as planned. I didn't have enough blanket to complete the cover up, or maybe I didn't dig deep enough, oh well, there's always next time.

It's called Monday Motivation, you must ease into the day, if you start off all bouncy and chipper then you lose momentum between your naps. There's nothing worse than dragging yourself through a Monday, nap first and be refreshed before the shenanigans start.

I brought something in from outside, dropped it on the floor, was beginning to dance around and bark at it, when all of a sudden I heard this screeching noise. It was The Warden, she cordoned off the area, dad came running in to investigate, there was some wild speculations about what it was I dropped on the floor. Dad scooped it up with a paper towel and threw it out, it was not alive, could've been a shining leaf, and nobody wanted to smell it. Well that sort of dampened the spirit of the moment.

After a rain you have to expect a few delays on your walk, the ground is oozing with fresh scents.  I've got my nose to the ground and it's in overdrive, so be prepared to take a deep breath and relax the leash. The snowplows have dug up a lot of earth over the winter and these particular mounds are of great interest, a lot of my friends have left messages, worth a little extra attention. We'll get home eventually, all in good time.

The Warden has too many rules when it comes to washing the sheets, first of all I have to get up before the sun comes up, what's up with that. There was a bit of a struggle ripping the sheets out from under me, all this because it's during non peak time, saving energy. I'll have you know that that most of the morning is my non peak time and I'm saving my energy.

I was in the kitchen supporting mom while she tried a new recipe for an apple cake, I tried a piece of apple which I spit out, not off to a good start. Dad taste tested the cake several times, then told mom to hide it.  I recommended cream cheese icing, everything tastes better with cream cheese. My suggestion for gravy was turned down.

I noticed that dad was really busy and needed a break, so I faked wanting to go outside. Once he got up to let me out I turned around and jumped up on the papers he was marking. It's important to be reminded to get up and move around, scratch those you love, maybe even chase them around and give treats. I'm always available if you need a distraction.

Timing is everything, Chef Mom is making soup so I'm waiting until after the vegetables are shredded. The meat always goes in last, that's where I show up, I sit quietly and patiently waiting for the cutting board filled with my share. Well, it's a few leftover remnants and after I finish with the cutting board it has a nice glossy sheen. I really don't see the fuss to scrub the board like it was contaminated, I had it spit polished clean.
